Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2014 08:53PM raro wrote: My onc started with a chemo but then switched to hormonals, and I did very well on them. I was 45 when diagnosed with stage 4. I did TAC 4 years earlier (ick..you have my sympathy!) and I was nervous at first about going off chemo...somehow the hormonals just don't seem like they're fighting the cancer as much or as well, but for me they were incredible. I'm 5 years out now, and while I'm on a great chemo (Gemzar) I'd much rather do the hormonals! But if they do them, remember it might take a few months to be sure they work. My onc said chemo does show results faster, but once the hormonals start working, they can do a good, even better job than chemo, so I wouldn't be afraid to give it a try. Good luck either way, and I hope you get better soon!

Posts.Title: Halaven and QT interval raro Leah_S

Posts.Content: raro wrote: So I've been on Halaven for 6 weeks now, and my tumor markers are down to zero. All good, I thought. I went in for my scans today at the hospital. I had just had the CT dye added to my IV, which of course always makes me feel flushed and weird for a minute or two. But I sat up and promptly felt extremely weird. The nurse asked if I was okay, but it felt like there was pressure on my ears and her voice was very far away. My head felt really heavy and I knew I had to lie back. Next thing I knew, I was lying back on the table and a bunch of nurses are nervously asking if I'm okay. They took my blood pressure: it was 60 over 40. And that was after lying down a few minutes. So they wheeled me about 10 steps down the hall, where conveniently, the ER is. After a few tests, the ER dr. said that my EKG was "a bit off" and showed a prolonged QT interval, meaning the time it takes to recover from one beat and start the next is longer than it should be. I've had an EKG before, this is new. Well, okay, what does that mean? He said I'd have to stay the night so they can monitor me. It was 10 a.m. so I was not happy. Plus it means yet another day of missed work. But then I started looking up on good ole Dr. Google and found a list of meds that can cause this condition. First among them is,...you guessed it...Halaven. Seriously?! I find a chemo that is mild enough to tolerate and it causes heart problems?! I'm not 100% sure if it's the chemo, but the only other drug I've been on (Lexapro) that can cause it I've been on for over a year, so I don't think that's it. I just don;t know what is going to happen. I don't want to switch chemos, but one of the side effects of a prolonged QT is sudden death, which I would prefer not to have, either. Gaaaahhhh!!! So you have the baby, and if things go downhill, you write her a bunch of letters and scrapbooks so that she/he will always know how much they were loved. You could live for decades, for all anyone knows!

Posts.Content: Oct 9, 2014 09:34AM raro wrote: CT and bone scans are to tell where the cancer is located. PET scans tell how active they are. The more PET scan spots light up, the more active the tumor. Insurance companies don't want to pay for them because they are more expensive and because CT and bone scans pretty much can tell you if the cancer is progressing.  As to cancer in the skull, I have several spots, and most oncs I've dealt with have said repeatedly that they "rarely, if ever" push into the brain. Well, looks like mine are doing just that. If you do have mets to the skull, I would definitely push for a brain MRI for a baseline. They don't usually do brain MRIs unless there are actual symptoms of brain mets (headaches, vision changes, etc.) but if you at least get a starting one, you'll have something to compare it with if you ever do have symptoms.  In the meantime, I'd find another onc. This one doesn't sound very invested in your care.  Oh, and my onc said the only real way to tell knee spots as arthritis vs. cancer is that arthritis tends to be in both knees, and cancer in the knee isn't as common. It's mostly just guesswork.

Posts.Content: raro wrote: I know there was a thread on here about ritalin, but it's almost midnight and I couldn't find it. It doesn't matter anyway..I just wanted to share that for me, this has been a MIRACLE drug! I tried not to expect anything from it, but I had NO idea how horrible and exhausted I felt until I didn't feel that way anymore. I have spent the last 4 days doing things I haven't done in a YEAR! I cleaned out my entire room, moved furniture, danced with my kid to 80s music, and went for a 2-mile walk with a friend. I know this isn't for everyone, and I hate to sound like a sales rep, but I wanted to share how much better I feel. I feel human again, for the first time in forever. I am planning projects around the house, laying down tile, ripping up carpets, painting walls. I know I can't take it after 4 or I'll be up all night, so I expect an evening crash, so I don't plan much for evenings. But the extreme exhaustion, dragging myself to work and barely functioning...it's just gone. Yes, I'm still tired, but not in the same way. Anyway, I just thought I would share. Who would have thought, even a week ago, that I would be thankful on Thanksgiving for a bottle of pills that have given me my life back?!? Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2012 06:41PM raro wrote: I'm sure God DOES save us if we pray...but our definition of "save" might be a tad different from God's. I know from my own research on how food is processed in this country that the government is a fallible entity made up of people who may have other issues than our health to think about. But I'm in no way a conspiracist. I just believe that knowledge is power and that even though there are tons of snake-oil salespeople out there, there are also some common sense natural or alternative things that could help. The thing is, I don't think anyone will find "the cure" for breast (or any) cancer. I think they will find a series of cures, because cancer is so incredibly individual. As my onc said, you could have identical twins with identical cancers, and one will respond to a treatment while the other won't. So I'm kind of leary of people who claim that "this worked for me, so it will work for you!" I would research as much as you can about each treatment and then go from there.

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2010 09:02PM raro wrote: Just thinking aloud here... If estrogen and stress are related, is it possible that stress plays more of a role in hormone-positive cancers? I was just glancing at all of you all's responses, and Elaine is the only one who wasn't stressed before her diagnosis, and she's ER/PR negative. I could be way off, but it is interesting... As for me, I am totally convinced that grief brought on my cancer. I may have gotten it later in life (I was 39 at original diagnosis), but my husband passed away after 18 months of marriage, leaving me with 2 teens and a 5-month-old. And my dad died during that time, too. Then my best friend. So yeah, lots of stress. I would love to know the cause of it because if we knew the cause, we could try to undo whatever it was that started it all. Just because I think I know WHY it started doesn't mean I know HOW it started. I often wonder, just what was I doing when that very first cell divided screwy and ended up cancer?! I will never know, and I don't beat myself up or blame myself, my lifestyle, or my diet. Other people eat, live, and work far worse than I do and don't get cancer. But I think we all search for answers. We all seem to have bits of the puzzle, but for each person it is totally different, and that's the frustrating part! Two people with the EXACT same type of cancer, same genetic makeup, and one will respond to a drug that the other won't. That is frustrating enough to make me never want to be an oncologist!!!

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2013 06:06PM raro wrote: Tweety, I see that you had TAC chemo before. When I had recurrence and my onc told me I would have to go back on chemo, I just started crying. I said my body was tired and I just could not do that again. His response was that TAC and its components are among "the most brutal" chemos there are. He assured me that not all chemos are so intolerable. I am currently on Halaven and was very worried because I have very few symptoms and feel better than when I was on Aromasin/Afinitor. I thought maybe it wasn't working. But in 2 months it shrunk my tumors by over half and brought my tumor count to zero. I'm not saying you should try Halaven or any other chemo, just that there ARE more "gentle" chemos out there, and hopefully your onc takes into account your quality of life. My onc at first wanted to put me on Xempra but said that it is a tougher chemo and while it might do the job, my quality of life might suffer more. I appreciated that he was concerned about that. Whether you decide to try another chemo or to stop treatment, you can be assured that many of us will be here to support you in whatever you choose. And regardless, I hope you have a fabulous, restful, wonderful Thanksgiving and Christmas.

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2014 04:27PM raro wrote: Hi, Deb, I'm currently on Gemzar, and it is one of the easier chemos. I've been on most of the chemos/AIs you mention, and Gemzar for me is probably the easiest. I make sure I eat a lot of fresh fruit for 2 to 3 days after and it prevents constipation. Otherwise, that's the main side effect. My hair hasn't thinned, surprisingly. Like a lot of chemos, it hits you with a bit of fatigue on the 2nd or 3rd day. I get it 3 weeks on and 1 week off. I also get a steroid IV with it, which makes me wonder if that's what delays the fatigue for a few days. I'm not complaining, though! I did have Xeloda several years ago and didn't last more than 6 months before progression. I don't remember much about it except being relieved that I didn't have the hand-foot thing...but I do remember having to lower the dose because I couldn't tolerate it. I'm amazingly (and very gratefully) sturdy when it comes to blood counts; I almost never have too low counts, so it must have been just feeling crappy that caused them to lower the X.  If you're going from X to Gemzar, I'd say you're onto much bigger and better things. I sure hope it works for a very long time!

Posts.Content: raro wrote: I got my latest PET scan results, and my doctor is confused. Not exactly what I expected to hear him say. I've had bone mets for a year now, and the last scans showed the two spots dying out. So this one shows the two spots stable (good, yes?!) and barely lit up at all, but there are two new spots on my spine. The doctor says he isn't sure what to think...why would two new spots appear, yet the old spots are dying more? He thought maybe because I had rads to the main one, but the other, smaller spot never had rads and it's shrunk to almost nothing. Sooo...half my mets are responding to chemo, and the other half are sprouting and growing in spite of chemo?!? Has anyone had this happen before? He wants to do a bone biopsy to confirm that they are BC mets, because since I'm also being treated for thyroid cancer, it could be that...except that my thyroid cancer didn't spread to the lymph nodes, and thyroid cancer is almost always self-contained inside the thyroid anyway. Posts.Content: raro wrote: A few weeks ago, Gemzar was kicking my butt. It had been such an easy chemo that I was getting really depressed with all the side effects. Plus I've had this off and on pleural effusion in my left lung. The onc was getting perplexed because it looked large, but they went to drain it and the dr. said there wasn't enough fluid to drain! Then my PET scan said there was a "large, layering pleural effusion"! And I was having weird chills, extreme fatigue to the point where for 3 days after chemo I was bedridden and sleeping all day. And by the time I started feeling better, it was time for the next chemo. Well, it dawned on me suddenly to ask my onc, what if I took steroid pills for just  those few days where I was doing terribly? I do NOT want to be on steroids regularly, but what about a 3-day taper? He agreed to try, mostly because he thought it might help my lung issue.  Well, what a difference! Three decadron the day after chemo, then 2 the next day, then 1, then off until the next chemo. It killed whatever has been going on in my lungs, and it's just enough to get me through the worst few days. I feel human again!  I just thought I'd throw this out there for any of you ladies who are suffering from nausea and extreme fatigue for those few days after chemo day, but who don't want to be on steroids long-term. At least for now, it's a success! Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2014 07:22AM raro wrote: Reader, I know exactly how it feels. That's why I always call 2005 my Year of Hell. I did TAC and don't know if I got out of bed except to use the bathroom, go to dr. appointments/chemo, and to be shuffled off to the hospital in an ambulance. II did all 3 drugs at once because I stupidly wanted "to hit it with everything I can!" I mean, no matter hard it is, it's only for 6 or 8 weeks, right? Hah. I was so naive.  I remember my onc telling me that I'd be (I think, if I remember correctly) getting infused something like once every 3 weeks. I asked him why not once every 2 weeks because I was so gung-ho about getting it done. He actually shuddered. He said, "Absolutely not. You will need that extra week to recover, I promise." I thought other people could be wimps, but I could handle it! Until about 24 hours after the first infusion when I thought I would die and didn't care if I did. At the time, I had no health insurance. I called my onc's office and they were able to give me some Kytril which helped, but gave me serious headaches after long-term use.  One thing I have learned is that pretty much all meds come with a price. Trying to get the right balance is a process. I found that for me, Compazine and Phenergan were great oldies but goodies, but I could only take them at night because they knock you out. So if you want something to help you sleep, they are good ones (and cheap, too, if you have no insurance). They also come (gross, but apparently effective) in suppository form when you can't keep anything down. "Vitamin Z" (as my rad onc called Zofran) really helps, but for me it gives me horrid headaches long term. But you could try it at least in the daytime to see if it helps. And you may not get the headaches. The one good thing about Zofran is that it comes in a dissolving tablet. Tastes minty and just dissolves on your tongue so it's good when you're feeling pukey. And as for Ativan...although I really think it is a miracle drug, it comes with a price for me, too. The three things it does that are perfect for me are 1. helps hugely with anxiety,  2. helps prevent seizures  3. helps with nausea. Oh, and it also helps you sleep, too. The price I have to pay if I want it long-term? It can cause slight amnesia. I never had to worry about hallucinating (Why don't I ever get blue butterflies like Deb?!) but boy did it cause me to have memory loss. So now I take it occasionally and am fine. Sorry for the long post. But I think everyone here has the same idea...Find what works for you, and DEMAND that you get help. I don't know if this helps or not, but when I told my new onc after being diagnosed stage 4 was that I could never do chemo again after TAC, his response was, "TAC chemo is, bar none, the most difficult of ANY chemo for ANY cancer. NOTHING you take from this point on will ever be as difficult as TAC." So you can look at it as "No wonder my life sucks right now, but at least it's temporary," and knowing that this is likely the worst you'll ever feel. And in the meantime, please know we're all here for you and you can feel free to rant all you want. It truly sucks.

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2012 05:37AM raro wrote: Renegko, I had to comment on your cat...sometimes, cats know their owners are feeling bad. It can make them anxious, too. But other times, it's simply that they are determined to keep an eye on you. Whenever I get teary, my one cat (who normally ignores me) will get right in my face. She is trying to tell me to cheer up, or at least trying to let me know she is aware of my feelings. I think cats (and other animals) are sensitive to those sorts of things. They may not understand the issues, but they understand feelings. I got to the point recently where I could not remember the last time I was happy, could not remember how it even felt. So I knew I had to do something. We are bombarded with toxic chemicals every day, and our bodies and brains just can't handle it all the time. I don't know about the rest of you, but going from one multivitamin a day to a basketful of meds is depressing all by itself! If the antidepressant you're on isn't working, talk to your doctor. They can switch it, increase it, or add something else. There are so many days when I think, "Life isn't supposed to be this hard, is it?!?" and I look around and everyone else seems to just be going along quite fine. But "everyone else" doesn't have cancer or has to deal with what we have to deal with. You need to advocate for yourself and get whatever help you need, with no apologies.

But come on, it's not like they can't tell I'm a cancer patient! One thing that helped me, although I don't know if you can do it, Springwatch, is that since I'm on Gemzar every Monday, my onc gives me a steroid taper (3 pills Tuesday, 2 pills Wednesday, 1 pill Thursday). It gets me through the worst of the side effects and fatigue...for 3 days I feel human again, so I schedule everything important then. Then I crash on Friday through the weekend, but that's okay. At least I can prepare for it. Maybe you can ask your onc about it? For something like Taxol, I would think it would help hugely with your side effects. I do NOT want to be on steroids constantly, because I've been there and the long-term effects are...not nice, for me at least. But 3 days a week is just right.

Posts.Content: May 17, 2014 11:26AM raro wrote: Thanks for your support, everyone! I made it through the three days, and while I didn't entirely make it, there were no binges, at least. I allowed myself one of those Lindor chocolate ball things each evening, and boy did I enjoy them more than usual! And last night I wasn't really hungry but wanted to chew on something, so I ate a few Twizzlers. Didn't help much, and I realized that they didn't taste as good as they usually did. So I won't be getting them anymore.  My stomach has rebelled against the sudden intake of more fruits and veggies (and here I thought I ate a high-fiber diet!) but I think it's getting used to it. I can't tell if I feel better or not because I'm still focused on cravings at the moment, but I'm going to try to severely limit my sugar intake from now on.  I have been reading a lot about sugar lately. I also don't want to "be a Nazi about it," but I think for me, I kind of have to for awhile just to get it out of my system. A few things I have discovered: - Chronic sugar intake messes with our ability to tell when we are full. (This describes me to a T...I'll stop eating and realize I should have stopped 15 minutes before and feel queasy) - Even 100% whole wheat breads have the whole wheat ground into such a fine dust (so the bread won't feel too "heavy") that it only has a single gram more fiber than white bread, which means it isn't any better than Wonder bread)  This was a surprise to me, since I've eaten 100% whole wheat bread for years and thought I was doing good for my body.  - Our bodies process all white flour products exactly the same as sugar, because white flour and sugar are simple carbs that flood our bloodstream much faster than whole grains. - In 1980, very few adults had fatty liver (except for morbidly obese and alcoholics). Now, a third of adults have it. (Including me, as I found out from my CT scans awhile back) - The sugar that affects our brain and blood most quickly is fructose, which is found in fruits. But when we eat fruits, their fiber keeps the fructose from flooding the bloodstream too fast. But once high fructose corn syrup was invented, it goes into our bloodstream very quickly.  - Almost all packaged foods have added sugar, including ketchup, salad dressing, even ramen noodles! I checked that last one and yes, it's in the little flavor packets. I really hate that Italian dressing, which is perfectly fine when it's oil, vinegar and a few spices, has sugar added to it, which 99% of them do. I have to make my own, which is a pain.  Anyway, I hope I didn't bore you all with all of this. I don't really think that fasting from sugar is going to slow down the cancer or anything, but hopefully it can help me feel better and more able to fight it.

Posts.Content: May 17, 2014 11:10AM raro wrote: I think one of the other issues we deal with is that more and more, people want simple answers to complex questions. They want to know that using deodorant causes breast cancer, that you can prevent colon cancer by not eating processed meat, that if you eat blueberries you will cut your odds of getting cancer by 50%, etc. That's why I hate, hate, hate Prevention magazine. My mom gets it, and every single article is like that. Dr. Oz is like that, too. I know they mean well (at least I hope they do) but people who never eat blueberries often don't get cancer, and people who never eat processed meat get colon cancer. It's never that simple. But slap a pink ribbon on it and call us warriors, and everyone becomes "aware" of cancer and feels that if they cheer from the sidelines it will "make a difference" (whatever THAT means). To really get in there and understand this disease, to be a support to those of us with it, to tease out all the complex issues of cancer...THAT is what I wish people would do. It's shooting for the moon, of course, because most people don't want to risk having to really think or work hard...but hey, I can dream...
Posts.Title: Just wondering about the words of battle Boo123 riverhorse

Posts.Content: May 14, 2014 08:01AM raro wrote: Boo, I kind of go back and forth on the issue. I'm not usually offended by the terms,but I really don't like it when others talk about me as if my "battle" is such an inspiration to them. I get put on a pedestal and told how "strong" I am. That word annoys me, because first of all, I'm feeling pretty dang weak right now, and secondly, it's not like we have a choice. At my dr.'s office there's a great saying on his wall "You don't know how strong you are until being strong is the ONLY CHOICE." I mean, it's not often that you hear about people who get diagnosed with cancer ,so they go home to bed and stay there until they die. The whole "fighting" thing is pretty pointless, since by "fighting" they mean getting up every day and living our lives. I'd like to ask those people who use the "warrior" imagery what exactly they think we're doing as warriors? Having cancer is mostly just going through life while waiting. Waiting for test results, waiting to see if the chemo works, waiting in doctors' offices...not the ideal "warrior" image, you know?  I also don't like the warrior image for another reason, and I'm not sure how to put it, but it's been with me since day one. This cancer that I have...it's something that somehow, my body created. Whether I have faulty genes, or ate the wrong foods, or was exposed to the wrong chemicals doesn't matter. This thing was something MY OWN BODY created. So if I am "fighting" cancer, that means in a way that I'm fighting myself. I would rather think that I am "working with" the cancer to find ways to overcome it. Not that it will happen, but if this were a bacteria or virus, I could talk truthfully about fighting an invading force. This is more devastating in a way because it's as if the troops lined up to fight the enemy have turned on me instead. I hope that makes sense.

Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2014 08:50AM raro wrote: One of the things I read about recently in the paper having to do with end of life issues was a hospital that had some videos that they showed to family members about heroic measures. It was apparently a very blunt description of what the person would be feeling...in the movies, it's always portrayed as a few minutes' frantic "rescue" and then the person is breathing and doing just fine again. Well, this video shows that the person usually is in great suffering, that they are usually never as they were before, because their body has already begun its natural, shutting down process. Apparently, once people see the video, they realize that the prolongation of their loved one's life is not about the loved one, it's about themselves not being able to let go.  For me also, it's hard to see people in chemo who are obviously suffering from dementia, are extremely frail and elderly, and seem to have absolutely no idea what is even going on around them, but their (usually adult child) loved one is desperate to prolong their life. It's just sad how far removed we are from the natural processes of death that as a society we panic at even the thought of letting go.

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2014 06:54PM raro wrote: Stella, may I suggest that you absolutely NOT compare your pain with the suffering of others? Sure, there may be others who have it worse than you, but that doesn't diminish your suffering one bit. Pain is pain, period. And you have had enough of it to last a lifetime. We all feel the need to rant at times, and this is one safe place you can come and be heard by people who understand. I have done things I swore I would never do because I also have a guy at home who would be devastated without his mom. I just can't do it to him, if I have any say in the matter. I am not familiar with your entire story, but it sounds like you can't climb out of a hole if you don't get a boost. You need to take care of the physical pain as much as possible...there's no reason you should suffer more than you are already. Physical pain can very rapidly deteriorate to emotional depression. I hope you are seeing someone, taking an anti-depressant, or have enormous support in your struggles. Most of us here have gone that route, and it helps us dig out of the deep hole of depression. In the meantime, know that we are here to hold your hand through the rough spots.

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2014 08:48AM raro wrote: TexasRose, my daughter had that same hopeless, bleak outlook and kept telling me she couldn't afford doctor visits or medication. I told her she couldn't afford NOT to. But she still would not go (she lives with me, and it's hard for her to see me struggle, especially after witnessing my seizures). We compromised by her going to Walmart and buying a $3.00 bottle of St. John's wort and taking two a day.  It has made all the difference. Within a few days, I noticed that the total hopelessness was fading. Suddenly she could think of the future with interest instead of apathy. I know St. John's wort doesn't work for everybody, but it might be something your DH might be willing to try, since it's easy to get and doesn't involve sharing his worst fears with strange doctors, which many men have problems with.  I read an article awhile back that said that in Europe they use St. John's wort more than Prozac or other drugs and that for mild to moderate depression it is every bit as effective. Don't know about severe depression, but it sounds like your DH, like my DD, at least needs a jump start to get out of the dark hole he is in. Then maybe he'll be open to counseling if needed.

Did every scan known to womankind, and all the results were inconclusive. In short, my onc (with the input from pulmonology, radiology, etc.) has, by his own admission, "no idea" what is really causing it. Many things we know contribute to it, but are they the cause?  CT shows an "area of consolidation" which in the pulm. dr.'s words, means that it's an area that they have no idea what is going on in. Could be cancer (unlikely since fluid drained from there showed no cancer cells), could be pneumonitis, could be old scar tissue, fluid, pus, whatever.  So  I finished the Gemzar cycle and had no treatment for a week. I was feeling pretty good, mowed the front lawn, went up/down stairs without too many issues, etc. Then I got Gemzar last Monday, and I still felt good (steroids) but I knew that the nausea/fatigue would hit on Wednesday. Sure enough, I woke up feeling like I'd been hit by a truck, as usual....but I also realized that the horrible shortness of breath was right back again. Like there's a tight band around my upper ribs so I can't take a deep breath.  Saw the onc today because I was scheduled for Gemzar. I told him my observations and he was very concerned. He says that he is torn because it is very hard to determine...Is this lung issue a side effect of Gemzar? OR is it a reaction (i.e., a type of allergy)? If it's a side effect, I can bear it at least until Thanksgiving, when I have my next scans. If it's an allergic issue, we'll have to stop it. But it has been working so well that he is reluctant to stop it, since I only have a few options left.  He asked me honestly what I thought. Not dumping the decision on me, but because he cares what I think. I said I could manage to get through until my scans. But I'm second-guessing myself. My onc said that if it worsens, if I'm struggling to breathe while at rest, etc. I can call him and he will stop it immediately and/or send me to the ER. Part of me thinks I'll be just fine since I've had the issue for months. But part of me suddenly wonders, what if I get an anaphylactic reaction to this drug? Am I panicking over nothing? Or am I being sensible?! Help! Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Aug 5, 2012 09:02PM raro wrote: I almost died from my first port placement...and I would still do it again! My surgeon did the placement with no problem, but a few weeks later I started having heart trouble, and was taken by ambulance to the hospital, where they found that my port had broken and the tubing (6 inches of it!) had broken off and was sticking in a valve in my heart! They had to do a cardiac catheterization to retrieve it. They switched me to a PICC line, which I hated with a passion and which promptly got infected and ended with me in the hospital for a week. Then, 5 years later, I told my new onc that no way was I getting a port after what happened! He said that I had had a freak accident (we did notify the manufacturer, etc. at the time) and that the new ports were much safer. The surgeon even showed me how the pieces "locked in" so it couldn't just break. I was skeptical, but finally agreed. And I have had no problems since. I've had mine for 3 years and my only regret is that they didn't do a power port. But it's SO much better than using my veins! In fact, I was looking at my hand a while back and thinking, "Man, I'm getting old, look at all the liver spots I've developed!" and then realized that they were only on my right hand...where all my blood draws had been from! So yeah, get a port and be done with all the vein pricks.

Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2011 06:53PM raro wrote: I've been on Zometa for almost 3 years. I do remember the flu-like symptoms the first time, and the weird "zapping" sensation through my bones for a few days after, but like China said, unlike chemo, with Zometa the symptoms get better each time, not worse. I honestly can't think of a single downside to zometa. No symptoms at all. As to the ONJ, I spoke with both my oncologist and my dentist, and both of them said it was very rare (couldn't remember the last time they had dealt with it) and in most cases could have been prevented with better dental hygiene. Please tell your mom that it's a lot of worry over nothing. It takes 20 minutes for an infusion once a month, and it really strengthens the bones, especially if she isn't taking calcium. Can she at least take vitamin D? And were her kidney stones calcium based? I've had kidney stones a few times, but mine were mostly uric acid, not calcium deposits. In fact, if I don't take my calcium, I get terrible leg cramps.
Posts.Title: Anyone taking Zometa? mlrosen Mary-Lou

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2009 09:30PM raro wrote: One thing I have to say is that whatever you do, add humor as much as possible. If your kids can see you laugh about things, it seems so much less frightening. The first time I did chemo, I had my son shave my head. He was about 15 or so, and as I watched the hair fall, I had to really try hard not to have the tears fall, too. Instead of crying, I grabbed the three wigs I had bought and tried them on all my kids (at the time, 15, 14, and 4 years old). My kids laughed hysterically to see the 4-year-old in a wig, and they still talk about the fun night we all goofed off with the wigs. My little one is now 7, and the way I explained to him was that a few cells got loose and set up shop in my sacrum. When I explained what the sacrum was, he said in tones of total disbelief, "You mean you have cancer in your BUTT now?!?" So now it's not metastatic cancer, it's mom's butt blob. Somehow it's easier to deal with it by making fun of it or laughing at it. Because we all know if we don't laugh, we'll cry. One thing I can say is that my kids and I are much closer than their friends and friends' parents are. They've been through so much that it has brought out a compassion and wisdom that they probably wouldn't have had otherwise. Even so, I wish they could have gotten the compassion and wisdom some other way!

Posts.Content: Aug 5, 2012 11:28PM raro wrote: I read all my scans because I got tired of doctors taking too long to get back to me! My first scan, when I knew I was stage 4, I got a PET scan on Wednesday and found out that my onc was going to be on vacation until the following week. I called the PET scan people and asked them to fax my record. They were very good about it. I used to be a medical transcriptionist, so I was familiar with a lot of the terminology. But even though I have a new onc and he is wonderful, occasionally I find something he misses. Like this week I got my pathology report from a craniotomy. I knew it was mets in my skull, but was surprised to find that it was "markedly progesterone positive." I had JUST had a biopsy the week before in one of my lymph nodes, and the results there were only estrogen positive. Not that it makes a difference in treatment, but I thought it was interesting. I'm firmly of the opinion of my old boss, who used to say, "Nobody ever died of an overdose of information." It is what it is, whether I see it or not, so I'd rather see it!

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2010 05:47AM raro wrote: Myra, my onc started me on Xeloda first, saying that if that didn't work, he would add the Tykerb. Can you ask your onc if you can do just the Xeloda? Just in case it's the Tykerb that is causing all the problems. I am on Xeloda and have very little nausea at 4000 mg/day, although others might have more nausea. Also, I didn't find Zofran as helpful this time round as last time. There are plenty of other anti-nausea drugs, from the oldies-but-goodies like compazine to the newer ones like Kytril. Before you give up, maybe you can see if you can alter some things. Also, did you just start at 3000 mg/day? My onc had me start with one pill twice a day for three days, then 2 a day for 3 days, etc. until I got to my current dose. The dr. said if it's too much, we can tweak it until I get a dose I can tolerate. So far, I've been grateful to be able to tolerate the whole amount, but it's good to know I can change it if necessary.

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2014 08:08AM raro wrote: I have. It was very plain and simple. It's just like doing chemo (without the chemo!) except they do it with a machine...can't remember which, but I think sonogram. You just lie there and they inject a CT dye in and watch where it goes. For me it was because they could get fluids in but no blood out. The doctor said, "Yup, the dye goes in just fine. Here's where you can see it," and showed me a cloudy area that was slowly moving out of the port...it was kind of cool to watch. But then they couldn't get out any blood. It was funny because I had chemo the next day and it worked just fine after that, with no treatment or anything.  Never had a microleak, but like I said, it's not a big deal to get a port study, fortunately.There was the usual prep stuff that took the most time ("change into a robe from the waist up," etc.)but the actual procedure took maybe 10 minutes.

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2012 12:11AM raro wrote: Lynn, have you ever tried Lidoderm patches? They are great for muscle/bone/nerve pain. Unfortunately, they don't come in full body size! Just 3 x4 inch or so patches that you slap on. No nausea, no side effects. I use them on my hips when they hurt like a toothache. There is also a liquid called Pennsaid that you spread on your skin and it absorbs it. I know these are more localized and not as helpful as a narcotic that can reach every single pain, but they don't cause side effects so you might want to at least look into them. I LOVE the pain patches. You can use up to 3 at a time and they really work for me. I had that kind of horrid pain when I had Neulasta shots. Felt fine one minute, like a 90-year-old the next minute. Fortunately it went away after a day or two, but it's scary if you aren't expecting it.

Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2014 10:04PM raro wrote: I second what pajim said...depression is NOT a weakness! You are carrying more on your shoulders than anyone should. You do NOT have to hide it from your husband, either. I assume it's an attempt not to worry him, but that's what marriage is for, to join together to face life's trials. If both of you are trying so hard to protect one another, you'll end up in your own little worlds and miss out on the immense support you can offer each other. Even both of you admitting you're scared stupid can be a support!  It took me awhile to admit that I needed to take meds for depression. I kept saying that "It's not a chemical imbalance, I'm just grieving!" Well, who cares what causes it?! Taking meds (in my case, Lexapro) has helped me function instead of being a weepy, watery mess. Once you get the depression under control, you can face any other issues you have to. Without help, everything seems hopeless. There is no need for you to struggle with depression on top of cancer.

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2012 10:26PM raro wrote: I am sorry you had to join us, but welcome! I'm 46 with a 10-year-old, and he was my first thought when I was diagnosed. I have extensive bone mets and a few small liver mets, and I've been doing this for 3 years. You are not alone. We're here for you. You can't help but have your mind "go to dark places," because you have to face the possibility of worst-case scenario. But you don't have to stay there. There are other, better-case scenarios that are probably more realistic than the worst. As to our children, I think they can become stronger and more sensitive to others. Not that they are better off because of our cancer (NOT!) but that dealing with something like this can make a lot of kids more mature simply because they have endured more. My son has been dealing with my cancer since he was 4. He occasionally gets anxious, but mostly he is able to adjust. Right now I'm stable. I don't give him a lot of details, but he sees me take handfuls of pills and I go to a lot of doctor visits, so it's out there for him to see. But we spend much more quality time together, not because "I could be gone by next year" but because we know how precious life is.

Posts.Content: raro wrote: Hello, Ladies! Sadly, Mum is not doing well. I'm not sure when she last updated you, so I'll give you a rundown from December. Mum spent the week before Christmas in the hospital. She was released on Christmas Eve, on a constant flow of oxygen. The week after Christmas, she went back to the hospital. That time, they started treating her with Navalbean. She went to the ER in mid January, and came home with a walker. The last week of January, she was struggling to breathe even with her oxygen turned up to 5 (the highest that particular machine went), so she was admitted to the hospital yet again. She was released to in-home hospice care last Tuesday. Her body can't handle any more treatments. We have a hospital bed set up in the living room, but she hates it. She gets up every 10-20 minutes all day and night. I found that a Flexeril and two Ativan let her sleep for about 3 hours, but I don't want to over-use it. She says she's scared of the bed, especially when we put up the rails on both sides. She gets really upset when we try to talk her out of getting up. She feels held captive, but she's also confused. For example, she heard us talking about the wheelchair and where to put it, and she thought she was going to the hospital. Do you have any ideas of how to keep her comfortable and calm? We wouldn't mind her getting up so much if she could do it on her own, but she has to have help to stand up, and then it takes lots of effort for her to lay comfortably, only for her to try to get up again 5 minutes later. It's wearing us all out, but we don't her to have to go to a nursing home. Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2013 07:18PM raro wrote: Some of my family have a really hard time with my illness, which I understand. My brothers can be clueless. One brother commented that he guessed I was still single because "well, with the cancer, nobody would want you." He didn't mean it to be rude, but we joke that he is in an ivory tower while the rest of us are in the trenches. When he or my other brothers try to tell me I'm "not dying, right?" because I "look fine," I usually respond, "Of course I'm dying. I'm just trying to do it as slowly as possible." They really only want for me to be happy, but they don't usually get that I have had to find my own happiness within the parameters of cancer. Even when I am truly happy, there's a sharp current of pain or grief or...something, I don't know. But it's there, and I will not deny it. But I also won't let it ruin my life.  As to nurses, when I was in the hospital a month ago with pneumonia, most of them were wonderful. But one was a total jerk who didn't want to deal with the whole bedpan thing. I literally could not sit up in bed without my heart racing and struggling to breathe. He kept saying, "You can get up to use the bathroom, come on, just breathe!" (Hello, I have pneumonia, I'm here because I CAN'T breathe, duh!!!)When he finally realized that I COULD NOT get up, he sighed loudly, shoved the bedpan under me, handed me a wad of toilet paper and stomped out. What a weasil. They moved me to the ICU for a week after that. But if only I had just BREATHED, I would have been fine!!!

Oops, too late for me!" and then they look terribly embarrassed. I do try to eat well, but there are times when dang it, a donut is what I want, so a donut is what I'm eating! I'm sure there are those who will shake their heads at my funeral and say, "if only she didn't eat that last donut..." Let them think that the next time THEY eat a flippin' donut!

Posts.Content: raro wrote: I know a lot has been said about breast cancer "survivors." I have pretty much ignored the word, but I had time in the doctor's office today that made me stop and think. (I told my onc that he REALLY needed to get new magazines because everything he had was either some golfing magazine or a cancer magazine, usually a year out of date..) Anyway, flipping through the cancer magazines (sorry, I hate golf), I noticed a pattern. I don't remember the title (something about "Living with Cancer" I think) but every article had a common theme. Didn't matter whether they were discussing thyroid cancer, breast cancer, or leukemia, it was the same thing: How to make it through treatment.  It's pretty sad when someone with cancer looks at an entire magazine about cancer, and there is not ONE article about long-term, permanent treatment. Every article had the word "survivor" in it, complete with pictures of happy looking bald people or families looking chipper and relaxed. No articles about how to talk to friends and family about being in treatment forever. No articles about how to handle "the Talk" with your onc, or how to choose good hospice care. In fact, they frame the idea of stage four with things like, "There is always the worry that things won't go the way we want," or "Anxiety about worsening disease can be stressful." It's like we're invisible. We aren't pink and pretty, so let's focus on what cancer patients really want, which is to be told only good news, only positive stuff. Heaven forbid someone should actually be called (gasp!) terminal.  Like I said,I know this has been discussed before, but I just wanted to rant to people who get it. My family is very sympathetic, but they just nod and agree with me and I don't think they get it at all, sigh... Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2014 03:09AM raro wrote: Hey, all, I've been on Halaven since Sept. 2013. My CTC went from 157-ish to zero in three weeks. But a few weeks ago I started having more aches and pains and was sure it was becoming ineffective. Had my scans last week and nope! Still stable! CTC is at 3, so I know it's still working.  I have a lot of fatigue and neuropathy in my legs. It started in my feet during Abraxane, and it's gone up past my knees. My onc is very concerned with quality of life, so he put me on 1 week on, 1 week off, and said that it's still okay to lower the dose. I told him I was nervous about lowering it so much that it's not effective, and he said it was in the literature that it's a viable option. He said it's akin to a loading dose vs. a maintenance dose.  Fortunately, my blood counts have been really good, so I haven't needed any neulasta, etc. The hair that fell out the first month is already a half-inch long again, so that's good. Almost no nausea or mouth sores. I take Neurontin for the neuropathy, but I don't know how well it's working. The only thing that really works is skipping a week when it gets bad! Here's to a looooong run for all of us...just for the Halaven! (get it? Hehe...lame, I know...)

Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2014 08:48PM raro wrote: A few thoughts.. Regarding your MIL sharing your business with everyone...Unfortunately, you can't control the actions of others. You tried to set boundaries and she did not respect them. Maybe now is the time to tell her, "You chose not to respect my wishes. Therefore, I really cannot trust you in this. From now on, I will not share my medical information with you." If she has no information, she will either move on to something else, or she'll spread rumors about how mean and horrible you are. In fact, she would probably count on your not wanting to "look bad" to others as a way to manipulate you.  The sad truth is, all the issues you mention are HER problems, and you can't force her to do the right thing. Can't force her to do anything, in fact. So, given her free agency to be as much as a jerk as she wants, the only thing YOU can do is to protect yourself. I agree that you need to set your finances in order. (Then, wicked me, I would thank her sweetly for suggesting the idea in the first place and tell her that you have followed her advice and gotten your finances all set, letting her know that all your money is spoken for, ignoring any questions about whether or not she will get any...) As to your husband, that's a hard one. He probably has spent his entire life walking on eggshells because to go against her means to face her wrath/manipulation/withdrawal of affection and to be portrayed as such a horrible person that it has always been easier to let her get her way. My daughter, whom I love with all my heart, had a tiny streak of that...when upset, she would lash out enough that sometimes people let her get her way in order to avoid dealing with the drama. I think I have helped her to see herself as others do, and she is much better about it. Your husband may need to be faced with two very plain options:  1. He could continue deferring to her and thus the problem will remain long after you are gone. Or 2. He could gently but firmly stand up to her, with you by his side, showing her that you are a team. As a bonus, if he were to do this, he would have a vaster amount of respect and appreciation from you, and he might find that your love and connection is far superior to the superficial relationship he has with his mother.

So I look up "Medically needy" on all the government sites I can find, and all that I can find is impossible for my 3-cell brain to understand. For example: "Each source of income received by a member of the FU/BU is evaluated and the countable amount determined based on the policy in this chapter. The countable amount of each FU/BU member’s income is added to the countable amount of the income of all other FU/BU members. That total is used to determine the income eligibility of each individual within that FU/BU. The FU/BU’s total countable income is compared to the income limit that is applicable to the individual’s classification and to the number of members in the FU/BU." Huh? All I want to know is, if I'm medically needy, is there an income limit that if I exceed it I will be kicked out of Medicaid? There is no way I can afford Obamacare. I'm getting a little frantic here. I can't even find if the income limit is anywhere near the Federal Poverty Level (like, some programs say "200% of the federal poverty level", etc.) I've tried local, state, and federal handbooks on line, as well as non-government programs, but I can't find this information anywhere! Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2014 11:19PM raro wrote: Thank you all  so much! I went in today for my usual chemo but asked if I could have this week off instead of next, because my body has been through so much. My regular onc was not there, but the head nurse knows me pretty well and said it would be no problem. She asked me a bunch of questions and we have both pretty much decided that the SOB has been caused by too rapid weight gain over too short a time. She also said I was anemic, but when I asked about taking iron, she said no, my iron was fine. I asked what the heck is meant by anemic, then?! She explained that according to my blood tests, my blood is fine, but the chemo makes it so that my heart and body just don't produce enough blood, so my heart rate is always a bit high. (It averages maybe 105 but goes up very quickly). My lungs have felt much better today, which we both thought is likely related to the fact that I've been off steroids for a few days and I'm losing all that water weight and food cravings.  One thing I've learned from my kids is that it is TOTALLY understandable why in ancient days people thought seizures were caused by evil spirits. My kids are getting to be experts at how to handle them, but I can tell they are still majorly freaked out by it.  And next time I go to the hospital, I am bringing my bedside fan and 13 of MY OWN PILLOWS!!! :-)

Posts.Content: Aug 13, 2014 12:50PM raro wrote: Well, I have decided that the SOB is due to my gaining so much weight over the past month or so from the steroids. It pushes up against my lungs, and since my left lung has had so many issues, it's more likely to be affected. Since I took off chemo this week, I've noticed I've lost a little bit of weight,and it's made all the difference. So I guess my instinct was right.  My onc ordered an MRI for tomorrow to be sure my brain is okay after the seizure. He is concerned that my skull mets are pressing on the brain, and if so, he will give me a spinal tap and insert chemo into the spine/brain to hopefully zap it. He doesn't think it's a big deal but he wants to be certain.  In the meantime, I spent ALL DAY yesterday in bed! And for once I didn't even feel like a slacker. I just gave myself a treat and slept off and on throughout the day and read a lot and watched TV. My youngest 2 kids and I have a tradition of reading all the Harry Potter books each summer. So we're on book 6, and aside from the great story, I love being able to read with my kids. My daughter is 25(!) and my son is 12, so it's not like they're even little kids! But it's the best part of my day. Then my son and his wife come in (I have a king-sized bed, which has become my office, my study, and everything else...) and we all just talk about life. That is such a golden time for me.

Posts.Content: raro wrote: ...but I really, really don't want to go to the ER and waste a whole day for something that might be minor...!  Here's the deal, and maybe you gals can help me decide what to do. Of course, things always get worse over the weekend, don't they?! Had pneumonia a year ago, very severe. Have had fluid around left lung since then, mostly with no symptoms. Since starting Gemzar, (which has a side effect of shortness of breath, and in rare cases can severely damage the lungs to the point of fatality) I've had a crackle in the left lung. They drained 1/2 a liter of fluid, but the crackle has persisted. Put me on steroids for 3 days after infusion, which helps me feel great, but has caused severe weight gain...and the crackle persists. Onc has been ambivalent about switching chemos because I don't have many left and because it has worked so well with so few other side effects.  So I get the infusion Mondays, 3 out of 4 weeks. The past few weeks have gotten steadily worse with regard to shortness of breath. Last week I was able (VERY slowly) to swim 16 laps if I paused between each one. This week I could barely manage half that.  So yesterday and today it's gotten to the point where I feel like there is a tight band around  my lower ribs and lower lungs. I have gained over 20 pounds in the past month from the steroids. I am out of breath and exhausted just puttering around the house.  So is it the weight that is making me feel like there is no room in my body for my lungs to expand? Or is it the Gemzar that is irritating the lungs and causing such severe shortness of breath? I was going to go in on Monday for my infusion and talk to the nurse...but I don't know if I can stand this horrid feeling of there simply not being enough room in my body for my organs. It feels like my lower ribs are separating from the pressure.  Has anyone ever experienced this?! Is it worth it to go to the ER and do a bunch of tests? I had the fluid drained only a month ago, so I can't imagine a huge tumor suddenly sprouting up in that time. I just dread going to the hospital. It stresses my kids horribly and I hate, hate, hate being there. I'm sure you gals can relate. Any advice?! Log in to post a reply

It says in the instructions (which I will keep and guard with my life, LOL) whom you HAVE to include as part of your household (myself, my son, and my daughter), and then there's a list of people you do NOT HAVE to include. My son and DIL live with me. They file their own taxes so I've considered them a separate family. If I include my son, I would have to include his income. He works 40 hours a week at $9.35/hour, which is barely enough even living with me, but it would certainly put us beyond the limit. BUT my DIL does not work currently, although she is looking. I can include her, but I don't have to include my son, according to the instructions. If we're a family of 4 instead of 3, I just might qualify for Medicaid.  And unfortunately, the mostly Republican government of VA decided not to expand Medicaid. My brother said incredulously, "You make $29,000 a YEAR on disability, and your medical expenses are about $20,000 per MONTH, and you don't qualify for Medicaid?!" This world is definitely FUBAR! At my church today, a woman I know came up to me and asked if I got her email. I said no, and she said that she had spent "a long time" talking to one of the state senators about me. Her husband used to be a state senator, so she has "inside" connections. She said she will resend the email, which has the number to call for a person who works for the senator and would be happy to help me. Must be nice to have such connections! We'll see what happens. In the meantime, thank you all so much for your comments and help.

She says she's scared of the bed, especially when we put up the rails on both sides. She gets really upset when we try to talk her out of getting up. She feels held captive, but she's also confused. For example, she heard us talking about the wheelchair and where to put it, and she thought she was going to the hospital. Do you have any ideas of how to keep her comfortable and calm? We wouldn't mind her getting up so much if she could do it on her own, but she has to have help to stand up, and then it takes lots of effort for her to lay comfortably, only for her to try to get up again 5 minutes later. It's wearing us all out, but we don't her to have to go to a nursing home. Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2014 02:40PM raro wrote: If you want, could your friend set up an account just in general, not for you specifically? Then you could decide for yourself what you would want to use and what you could donate to Metavivor or your doctor's office for those with no insurance? Just a thought.  I don't know if it's a good thing or a bad thing, but nowadays when people are touched by something they throw money at it. Well, money helps. At least you know they're not donating to Komen or buying pink toenail clippers, right?  The idea of donating directly to a patient would likely mirror your own experience...a lot of people would feel offended or afraid of sounding like they're whining or begging. And there are many people who could use the money but haven't told anyone they have MBC. So I vote for: -If they know someone in treatment, advocate bringing a meal or doing laundry or helping clean their house -if they don't know someone personally, they can donate to a fund your friend can set up and then figure out how you can use it to benefit yourselves and/or others with BC.

Posts.Content: Jul 24, 2010 03:49AM raro wrote: Hi, Dejam, I was on Xeloda for about 3 months. Unfortunately, it didn't work for me, but there are tons of women here who got a lot of good out of it. Compared to chemo infusions, Xeloda is a breeze. Just a few pills a day, no needles! You do have to watch out for hand-foot stuff, though. I used a mix of petroleum jelly and lotion on my hands and feet twice a day and never had any peeling, itching, etc. But because I had neuropathy (numbness and tingling) in my feet from other chemos, I got neuropathy from Xeloda, too. It did make me tired and forgetful, but I was still able to work just fine. And you usually don't have the horrible days like you do with infusions when the chemo "hits" you. I didn't really have any other symptoms. There are other threads here about Xeloda if you want other opinions, too. Like you, I have a lot of family support, but sometimes it's good to know you're not alone on this trip.

Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2014 05:45PM raro wrote: Bonita, my dad passed away from Lewybody dementia. Once the geriatric neurologist realized we were not looking for a cure, just to keep him comfortable and safe, he relaxed and wasn't so defensive. We talked about hospice and were able to keep him comfortable in his last days.  For me, there was something so incredibly awe-inspiring about helping someone pass from this life to the next. I can't even think of words big or serious enough. He was thirsty so we made sure he was well hydrated, but he didn't seem to be in any pain or discomfort. My brother remarked that we often talk about the miracle of birth, but never about the miracle of death, how the body instinctively knows how to shut itself down very efficiently. I wasn't really in the mood to hear a science lecture at the time, but I've often looked back and realized what he meant.  I hope your fathers final time with you is full of rest and peace and love. And as many pain-free days (for both of you) as possible.  Hugs,  Raro

I make lists of things I want to do each day. I try to make it simple, not too rigid or demanding. But I find myself bored because I can't do much anymore. The LAST thing I want to do is become a daytime TV junkie (daytime TV is so crappy I can't watch it no matter how bored I get!) How do you all deal with finding purpose in each day when the mind has so many ideas but the body won't cooperate? I'm on antidepressants, so I know it's not that. Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2013 09:13PM raro wrote: The question is, is this your problem or your doctor's? You may feel uncomfortable about talking about tough issues, but is he/she also uncomfortable? That could make things doubly hard. Any doctor worth their salt would tell you that there is no real answer to the question, but sometimes you just need to talk about it anyway. I am sure your onc has had this conversation many times and will have it many times in the future. So you bring it up by just blurting it out. It's not like you're going to surprise him/her. You could just say, "Look, I know you can't give me the date I'll drop dead, but based on my profile and all that, can you estimate what you would guess my life expectancy is? I know it could be way off, but I'm just curious as to your experiences with someone in my situation." Of course you could drop dead tomorrow or live 20 more years, but as long as both of you understand that, you might gain some insight from him/her. Or not. But if you want his/her opinion, you should feel free to ask, at least.

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2014 12:16AM raro wrote: Stella, I have two thoughts on this: Firstly, our kids will have good memories of us...not about the great, expensive vacations, although that will likely comfort them when we're gone. But what my kids (grown and young) have told me is that their best memories of me will be the times we have spent at home together, playing cards, reading together, praying together, even doing kitchen chores after dinner. I try very hard to have a sit-down dinner with my kids so that we can talk and laugh together. I don't always manage it, but those small moments are what our kids will hold onto in later years.  Secondly, as to pain...I am with Carolyn - Why on earth hasn't your doctor worked with you on pain?! I would park myself outside his door until he listened to me, because there is no excuse for living with such pain. I've been there, and it colors EVERYTHING you do. You can't enjoy anything when you're in pain, and the effect it has on our minds is huge. No wonder people get depressed when they're in pain! I was trying to find (unsuccessfully) a procedure that my rad onc told me about. When someone has bone mets that are extensive, there is a relatively new procedure where they give some form of radiation to the entire body. It's primarily done for pain. But when I looked up "whole body radiation" I got something completely different. Grr. If the Xeloda doesn't alleviate your pain, maybe you could ask your doctor about it. Either way, I hope Xeloda works for you for a long time. I do have to say that when I was on Afinitor, after awhile it REALLY wore me down. I couldn't believe that I was happier doing Halaven chemo than Afinitor/Aromasin. My quality of life was much better.

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2012 01:28PM raro wrote: I remember that story about a woman who got her degree at 85 years old. She had thought about doing it for years and told her friend, "But I'll be 85 when I graduate!" Her friend wisely replied, "Yes, and how old will you be then if you DON'T graduate?!" We know our time on this earth is limited. It sounds like this is something you want to do. If you don't do it, you could be looking back in a few years thinking, "Man, I could have had my master's by now, but I didn't think I'd finish, so I never started..."  Life is too short for regrets. Posts.Content: raro wrote: This is just not my day...week...month...summer...sigh... My DIL and I were working on the dining room floor this morning. We're installing a hardware floor. Well, I'm smart enough to know I can't do much, so I figured I'd be the driller and drill some screws into the subfloor. Maybe a half-hour of drilling, tops, and I took it easy.  Then I made sure to take my afternoon dose of oxycontin because I knew I'd probably be a bit sore, muscle-wise. Sure enough, I was a bit sore. But nothing I couldn't handle. I had my son slap on a pain patch. Then I noticed a slightly sharper pain in the ribs on the FRONT, as if the muscle pain in my back was going through to the front. I've never felt that before, but it wasn't that major and it didn't last, just kind of hurt if I moved a certain way. So I stuck a pain patch there, too.  All was well until, while I was sitting in my bed on my laptop, out of NOWHERE (I wasn't bending, moving, doing anything) I got the worst pain in my life. It was as if someone stabbed my back with an ice pick and it went right through almost to the front of me. I screamed and my DIL, who was in the room, raced over to see what was going on. I was in tears, but it went away. Then I blew my nose, and the pain seared through me again.  I have no idea what is going on. I'm afraid to move. It is the worst pain I've ever felt in my life, and I've felt a lot of pain! It's not a torn muscle, as far as I can tell. I don't think it's a nerve pain, although it was very sharp and defined. And I can still breathe okay, so I doubt it's lung-related. The best I could describe it is, like an 8-inch sliver of wood stabbing through my right side, a few inches below the shoulder blade. My DIL suggested all sorts of things, none of which would correspond to such a sharp pain. I was wondering, since I have extensive mets to the bones (including ribs), is it possible that I could have fractured a rib? I've never had a broken bone before, so I have no idea. Is it possible that the rib was so...I don't know, mushy with cancer? that it just spintered?!  I really, really don't want to go to the ER yet again. I'm thinking of just waiting it out and seeing what happens. In the meantime, I'm afraid to move, sneeze, wiggle, laugh, cry...even going to the bathroom was pathetic, because I moved so slowly and was so afraid that peeing or pooping would bring the pain back! (Sorry if that's TMI).  Have any of you gals broken a rib, and did it feel like I'm describing?! Any ideas? Please?! Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: May 4, 2009 06:25AM raro wrote: I had a biopsy for mine. It came out "inconclusive," so they repeated it. My onc basically said that although he was 95% certain it was mets, there really is no way to be sure of the cellular structure (how aggressive, ER, PR + or -, etc.) until they biopsy. Apparently, a secondary tumor can be genetically different from the original, which I didn't know. The biopsy was pretty simple, just basically a needle in my back. Didn't feel anything because I decided to take a nap, which the doctor found pretty funny. As my onc said,"We love scans. We scan for all sorts of things. Posts.Content: raro wrote: ...but I really, really don't want to go to the ER and waste a whole day for something that might be minor...!  Here's the deal, and maybe you gals can help me decide what to do. Of course, things always get worse over the weekend, don't they?! Had pneumonia a year ago, very severe. Have had fluid around left lung since then, mostly with no symptoms. Since starting Gemzar, (which has a side effect of shortness of breath, and in rare cases can severely damage the lungs to the point of fatality) I've had a crackle in the left lung. They drained 1/2 a liter of fluid, but the crackle has persisted. Put me on steroids for 3 days after infusion, which helps me feel great, but has caused severe weight gain...and the crackle persists. Onc has been ambivalent about switching chemos because I don't have many left and because it has worked so well with so few other side effects.  So I get the infusion Mondays, 3 out of 4 weeks. The past few weeks have gotten steadily worse with regard to shortness of breath. Last week I was able (VERY slowly) to swim 16 laps if I paused between each one. This week I could barely manage half that.  So yesterday and today it's gotten to the point where I feel like there is a tight band around  my lower ribs and lower lungs. I have gained over 20 pounds in the past month from the steroids. I am out of breath and exhausted just puttering around the house.  So is it the weight that is making me feel like there is no room in my body for my lungs to expand? Or is it the Gemzar that is irritating the lungs and causing such severe shortness of breath? I was going to go in on Monday for my infusion and talk to the nurse...but I don't know if I can stand this horrid feeling of there simply not being enough room in my body for my organs. It feels like my lower ribs are separating from the pressure.  Has anyone ever experienced this?! Is it worth it to go to the ER and do a bunch of tests? I had the fluid drained only a month ago, so I can't imagine a huge tumor suddenly sprouting up in that time. I just dread going to the hospital. Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2014 12:12AM raro wrote: Yikes! What an awful end to the holidays! I'm so sorry you have to endure such a lousy experience.  My son had to call 911 last year (he was 10) after I had had surgery for a met in my skull and my brain swelled enough that I had a seizure. He is a pretty good-natured kid, but I realized later that it is no small thing to see a parent in physical distress. I don't know how old your kids are, but just talking about it with them will go a long way toward calming their worries. Our kids have had to be more resilient than most. I think they have the ability to be in the land of DeNile (in a healthy way) much more than adults do, and in a short while your kids will likely just accept that this is one of those cancer things.  And in the meantime, YOU did not ruin the holiday for your family! It's just a stupid fact of cancer that it causes dumb crises like this. It doesn't erase any of the good times you have had already. I hope you have a speedy recovery and get through rads with no complications.

Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2013 11:21PM raro wrote: The one thing that hurts my heart a bit is that when I am bald, it frightens some children. I worked at a craft fair today, and went bald (it's my 3rd time, I hate wigs, scarves fall right off my head, and my "I'm having a no hair day" hat was getting old). Older kids would pass by (it was held at an elementary school) and keep looking at me out of the corner of their eyes, and I would give them a bright, cheery smile and they would usually smile back and be okay. But some of the younger kids would stare, wide-eyed and fearful, as if I were some monster that they couldn't name. I did, however, meet another crafter, a man with 4 elementary-aged kids whose wife died 2 months ago from a rare form of throat cancer. He looked at me and said quietly, "What you got?" It took me a minute to realize he was referring to my bald head. I told him and then he shared his story. I could tell he was just so lonely and needed to talk to someone who understood. Aside from knowing about cancer, I also lost my spouse when my youngest was 6 months old, so I understood him more than most. So sometimes being bald brings out the worst in people, while at others it brings out the best. I know that poor man was clinging to me (metaphorically speaking!) in desperation, just wanting to not feel alone in his pain. I just wish I could explain to all the little kids that I'm not really scary. I could explain to them if they stopped, but a lot of them were just walking by. Sigh.

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2014 11:09PM raro wrote: Wow, Chris, it just never ends, does it?! I'm so sorry you're dealing with all this. As to the brain MRI, my onc always said that there would usually be symptoms that would make him suspect brain mets. Well, when my skull mets started trying to break through to the brain, I definitely had symptoms: vision issues, severe headaches, etc. And it wasn't until about 2 years into my diagnosis that he suggested a baseline MRI just because he hadn't done it before. So not all MRIs are for brain mets. Your onc could just be being cautious. Also, considering that MRI results are MY records, I decided to return the next day and get the results myself. I thought I'd have to park myself in the hospital where it was done and argue all day. But nope, they printed out a copy and gave it to me with no fuss.  My onc is okay with that because he knows I can't wait for results and he knows I pretty much know the terminology. You might want to call the office of wherever you get the MRI (or talk to them when you do get it) and tell them you'll be stopping by the next day to get a printout of the results. You can stress that you do NOT need (unless you really want it) a copy of the images, just the written part. That way you won't have to wait forever for the doctor to tell you that your brain is (hopefully) JUST FINE.:-) Either way, we're here for you. This disease truly stinks.

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2014 10:57PM raro wrote: Wow, all of you, thank you so much! What a crazy 24 hours...I went off to the ER and waited 8 hours until they had a bed to admit me. I HATE that!!! They couldn't do a CT scan (which would have helped much quicker) due to my severe allergy to the dye, so they had to admit me to wait until they could do a VQ study or some such thing to rule out a blood clot in my lung. After one of the worst night's sleep in my life last night, I woke at 7 a.m. for the stupid test (which was actually mercifully short) and they said no blood clot. But my "D-dimer" was elevated, which is why they thought it could be that in the first place. The idiot doc on call was a woman who assumed that because the test was negative, I must be having an anxiety attack.  I said, yeah, then why can the ER docs hear "diminished breath sounds" and cracxkles in my left lung? Was I faking that?! She backed down a bit but seemed adamant that I was having an anxiety attack and needed to prescribe ativan. I told her I already had more than enough (which only confirmed in her mind that I was anxious) and she went on her way.  So I went home, utterly exhausted, and lay down on my bed to have a nap. My son came in to say goodbye as he and his big brother were on their way to church...only to once AGAIN find me in the middle of a grand mal seizure!! At least this time they knew what to do. My oldest son turned me on my side, my DD called 911, and within an hour of coming home, there I was back at the ER. I was really out of it (apparently they asked me 3 times if I could say the President's name and I couldn't tell them, although I have no memory of that).  The doc on call was a no-nonsense guy who was kind but honest, which is rare at such places. He said that if a person's neural pathways are already "set" toward a seizure, there are a few things that would cause it: 1. suddenly going off seizure meds (nope), 2. sleep deprivation (um, yup!) and 3., morning. He said many, if not most seizures of that sort happen in the first few hours of awakening. I realized I'd had 5 seizures so far, and ALL of them were within an hour or so after waking up. I'd never noticed.  He scoffed at the idea of anxiety "causing" seizures and rolled his eyes. He said it was likely my lousy night and it being right after waking up, and also because I usually take my seizure meds at 7 or so and the hospital didn't get them to me until almost 11 a.m.this morning. He said usually that wouldn't be an issue, but with the other stuff going on, it could have just added to things.  So anyway, the one nice thing is that my church has informed me that people are bringing meals every night for 3 days. I can't even imagine standing in the kitchen, let alone cooking, so I'm thrilled. Unfortunately, I don't know if I will be able to eat it...apparently when I seized, I bit my tongue pretty badly.  So now I have sores on either side of my tongue, pretty severe ones, as well as sores right at the corners of my mouth, caused by the chemo, I'm sure. So all it all, I can hardly swallow or eat. Maybe that will help me lose weight, haha.  Thanks again SO much for your thoughts and prayers. They were effective and comforting and did not go unnoticed.  :-)

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2012 10:25PM raro wrote: Blossoms, I have a little experience with skull mets. I had one right above my right eye. I couldn't feel it, but it gave me migraine-like headaches. The onc said that even though usually skull mets don't turn into brain mets, if it pushes long enough it will push through the meninges and into the brain, and we don't want that. So they surgically removed it. It was about 2 inches square, and they cut my skull from ear to ear, like a hairband would be. They cut out the tumor, put in bone putty and mesh, and superglued my skin back. (I can only say that in this forum, because most people start gagging at this point) I expected severe headaches for weeks afterwards, but It didn't hurt nearly as much as I would have thought. And they only shaved a small area of my bangs. My neurosurgeon is world class. The only complication was that I had a grand mal seizure the night I came home from the hospital. It was a relatively rare side effect caused by swelling of the area that put pressure on my brain. Although it terrified my son, who was (fortunately) sleeping in my king-sized bed with me, he was able to call 911 and I spent another night at the hospital. Never had another seizure, and the wound can hardly be seen. I also have a smaller tumor at the base of the skull, the "clivus," whatever that is. I told my surgeon it sounded vaguely obscene! He said surgery in that area would be a good 2-week hospital stay, and that gamma knife would take care of it in one shot. I'm planning on doing that soon. I hope some of this helps. It just seems so unfair that we always have to strive to keep a balance between having a coherant brain or being in pain. To be out of pain, you have to be drugged out of your mind, and if you aren't drugged out of your mind, you're in extreme pain! Grrrr. Rebecca
