Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2014 10:33PM raro wrote: I am physically addicted to oxycontin. If I go an hour past my usual time taking it, I get jittery and have major restless legs syndrome. I complained to my oncologist that if I had to be addicted in this way, the LEAST it could do was make me happy and relaxed. It has NEVER made me high, and in fact, I refer to it as making me "low," because I used to feel under water and mentally slow. Now, it's just there, it does its job. When I did radiation treatments, though, the rad onc, who was rather young and clearly though highly of himself, was concerned because I take the oxy 3 times a day instead of 2. I told him my regular onc and I had worked it out, and it was what worked for me. He went on a long rant about how it could cause me to take more than I should, I could overdose since the dosages were overlapping, yada yada. Well, I mentioned it to my onc, who is a colleague of him, and he blew his top! He said, "If it works for you, we are continuing it. If HE wants to take over your pain management for the REST OF YOUR LIFE, I'd be happy to transfer it to him. But if not, he needs to keep his big mouth SHUT about his opinions that have nothing to do with him!" I just started laughing because it was nice to have a doctor stand up for me like that. And it was all over 10 flipping milligrams of the stuff! My point is, we do what we have to do to get by. You don't owe anyone, even a loved family member, any explanation. If you and your daughter begin to make steps to make up, you might tell her that it's okay for you both to "agree to disagree" but not discuss it. I do remember being her age and talking to my future sister in law about her depression. Wow, was I so full of myself! I kept telling her things like "You just have to try harder," and "How can you drop out of college because you're feeling a little blue?!" I have long since apologized because I learned (slowly) about depression and how it affects people. So I try to be understanding and educate others about MBC. Because I think it was karma coming back to bite me in the butt!  I hope that you and your daughter can work through this and that she can learn that she doesn't have to agree with everything you do in order to support you.

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2012 09:57AM raro wrote: I'm no longer on faslodex, but I do know that ice can make it worse. The shot is thick and viscous, and you need heat, not cold, because cold slows it down and thickens it. I suffered from huge butt and hip pain from those shots until I got great advice here. You take a tylenol a half-hour before the shot, and as soon as you leave the doctor's office, you walk around the parking lot as briskly as you can. That gets the stuff moving throughout your body instead of just sitting like a gooey lump in your butt! Sometimes the shot would hurt months afterward, which is really weird, but it seems to be an occasional side effect.

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2014 06:14PM raro wrote: I have a friend from church who is HER2+ and stage 4. She was doing very well on Herceptin, and when she moved to this area, she just could not seem to face going to find an oncologist and continuing the whole thing. Her husband kept nagging her to go find a doctor, but she didn't. For about 2 years, she was on no treatment and was NED. But then symptoms started, and she is back on treatment. I think for her, she needed that denial period, but I don't know that I could do that. I've never been on Herceptin, but I also haven't been NED, either, so I guess I don't know what I'd do.  I guess the important thing is to support one another, even if we shake our heads at some people's decisions. I also know that sometimes when we haven't faced that exact situation, we think we know what we'd do.  I vividly remember telling anyone who would listen that when *I* had my baby, he was NOT going to be in a crib, because cribs looked like jails, and we were going to do the "natural" thing and have him sleep with us. Yeah, right. That lasted until he could crawl, and boy, did we then go out and buy a crib! I'm sure many of my friends were snickering behind my back. But I learned the hard way that sometimes when we're faced with something scary or bad, we react quite differently than we think we would. I don't know about the poster everyone is mentioning, but I figure, if it makes her happy to tell people she's in remission, or even cured, then so be it. I hope she is. But if she isn't, we will still be here to support her, because facing progression after telling everyone she might be cured must be even harder.

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2014 11:31PM raro wrote: Hi, ladies,  I don't post on this thread very often, but I thought I would share something with you.  I was a semi-professional genealogist years ago and still love researching ancestors, etc. Tonight I was looking for a birth certificate of some far off ancestor, and I came across a bunch of stuff I'd forgotten about. My dad's dad died of leukemia about 10 years before I was born, and I only heard great things about him from my dad. But aside from some pictures and his death certificate, he was just a name to me growing up.  But all that changed when his childhood best friend sent me some stuff a few years back. In among that stuff was a letter my grandfather wrote to him when he was 16...from France, where he had lied about his age in order to serve in WWI.  That letter is the only window into my grandfather's personality that I have. I have treasured not only the cool information he provides (he was a bugler and got regularly pelted with shoes when he played to wake everyone up!) but also it showed me what this stranger was like when he was a teenager, facing far more dangerous situations than I had ever dreamed.  My point is, for all of you who, like me, haven't started the diary/journal/scrapbook/letters for our kids, let yourselves off the hook a bit. Those of you with older kids will not forget you, and those of you with younger kids, there are plenty of things you can do that won't sound like "This is the Last Message from your dearly departed mother..." Just writing down your thoughts in general, not even about cancer, but what you think of your wacky cousin Hortense, or how much you hate pistachios, or how grateful you are that you live in a warm climate...ANYTHING will be treasured by your kids. The most fascinating details for them will be the most mundane ones. Having a child say, "Oh, THAT'S where I get that habit from!" or "I love that TV show, too!" creates a bond between you and your child that death cannot break.  Anyway, I thought I would share that. Sure, in my mind I will have written a letter for all my family members, my own eulogy, letters to people who annoyed me in life (so I'm not the most pure-hearted person all the time, so sue me), and I'll have all the important papers, passwords, etc. all nicely filed...will that actually happen? I have no idea. But I do know that my family members know how much I love them and that, while no amount of letters, videos, etc. would ever be enough for them, at least they will have an idea of who I was and what kind of person I was.

Posts.Content: raro wrote: I know the subject has been raised before, but I'm kind of at an all-time low right now. I think I just need a bit of encouragement, which you ladies are so good at doing! I work in a middle school teaching kids with emotional disabilities. It's always a stressful job, but I love the children and I really think I make a difference. But my colleagues and boss are a different matter. Colleagues seem to believe that I'm not a "real" teacher, despite my master's degree, because I only teach a half-dozen children. (A half-dozen children who are on enough meds to kill a horse, who curse at me and throw tantrums and get into fist fights and end up in mental hospitals...) But I love the kids so I can deal with that. But my principal...he is young and ambitious and new (2nd year) and seems to want total control. And for some reason, he has set his sights on me. Last week, he wrote me TWO letters of reprimand for my permanent file. One of them was because I wrote in a note to a sub that my students could "goof off" for the last 10 minutes of the period if they had been good. He told me that "goof off" was an "entirely inappropriate term" and that if I didn't understand that then "maybe you should be in a different profession." Gee, I had no idea that "goof off" was an obscenity!! But on the good side, I have a great union representative who is meeting with me tomorrow to help write letters of rebuttal. She told me that she had stopped by the human resources department and told the head of HR that if nothing else, she was demanding that this principal accept and acknowledge the fact that I have cancer and that he "darn well ought to deal with it." He makes a huge deal out of everything to do with the cancer, without actually ackowledging that I have it. For example, the HR people told me that on my leave slips I need to write "FMLA leave" (not that it really matters since I take sick leave,and then leave without pay once that is gone). So he emails me to complain that "I thought you had an ear infection. Why did you write FMLA when that wasn't related to your disability?" I told him that my treatments made me prone to infections, so it was related. I mean, seriously, what does it matter?! Another time, I wanted to be proactive, so I told him several days in advance that I would be taking off the afternoon for my scans. He responded with a curt note that he had not seen my leave slip, so he could only assume that I was trying to take off work "for free." Seriously?! When I've worked extra if I take so much as five minutes off in the past?! I'm just worried that I will lose my job. I can't transfer to another school because he put me on an "improvement plan" last year and won't remove it, even though I completed everything (and more) that was required. I can't move to another district because with these letters of reprimand, no one would hire me. I have worked here for 7 years and have had only good performance evaluations, and then this guy comes in and my file is down the toilet. I would give anything to just quit and go on disability, but I can't see how I could ever afford it. I have family who support me 100%, but they don't understand and they just hurt for me. My best friend died, as did my husband,and my friend who lived with me for 3 years and was like a sister to me had a psychotic episode a few months back and tried to kill me. Needless to say, she is now out of my life. So I'm feeling a tad alone and sorry for myself right now. Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2012 01:55AM raro wrote: Thanks. As tothe life insurance...My husband had worked for the airlines, and was let go after the industry temporarily tanked after 9/11. He lost life insurance, health insurance, everything. We survived on unemployment for a few months and then he got a high fever one night. The next day he was so "out of it" that I was alarmed and took him to the ER. He was admitted with sepsis and died that night. It was so sudden and nobody could believe it, least of all me. My SIL and I are very close, and she was pretty devastated, too. After a few months, she and I got to talking and we agreed that if I died, I would need some kind of insurance to care for my kids (at the time, they were 14, 13, and 5 months). She got the policy for me and has paid the premiums all this time. She is not the beneficiary, my kids are. If I died, she would care for my youngest, who is 11, since now my oldest 2 are out of the house. However, I think it would be a good idea to ask for a copy of it. SHe may have even given me one once, but if so, I have no idea where it would be. She would be happy to do that; she is very up front with money and stuff like that. Bon, I LOVE your idea about writing the certified letter! Do you think it's "going behind the back" of the union rep? (I call her the union rep because it's easy...it's actually the "education association." Not sure if that makes a difference. Everyone calls it the union, anyway). I really like the rep, but I feel that she just doesn't know what else to do except help me come up with defenses to all these nitpicky things. There must be 50 of them that he listed, half of them things that I already rebutted previously. I've been copying out all my emails, my improvement plan stuff, performance evaluations, etc. I even have a file box to help organize the stuff. It's just so pathetic! But you guys have given me ideas of what direction to take, and that makes all the difference!
Posts.Title: Jerk bosses raro

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2014 10:59PM raro wrote: Thank you all so much for your insight and caring. It definitely helps to know that I'm not the only one going through this and that there are things I can do. When I'm depressed, nothing comes to mind, so I appreciate the suggestions. Today I did a craft fair. I do them during the winter holidays but since I'm on disability now I figured I would try the spring ones. Well, we didn't even make fifty bucks, so at least I know I'm not missing much! But I came across a guy from the fall craft fair, one who had lost his wife to a rare esophageal cancer about 6 months ago. He was selling gourmet coffees a few booths down. It was good to see that he is doing reasonably well after his wife's passing. I think it was good for me to see that our loved ones can survive once we are gone. He will obviously always deeply miss his wife, but he is moving on slowly.  He shared a cute photo he took that he knew I would understand. He had cried out a few nights back for his wife, just to know she was there, sort of a "Give me a sign" thing. He told the kids to clean up after breakfast and then they went off to school. He went into the kitchen and saw two cheerios and a smear of milk that looked like a really cute smiley face. When his kids got home, he casually asked them what they had had for breakfast, and none of them had had cheerios. He admitted that maybe it was coincidence, but said, "Hey, I'll take it as a sign. It's just the sort of thing my wife would do."  It really cheered me up. The craft fair was a bust, but I kind of expected it to be. Then I came home and slept for 3 hours. I get tired of "taking one day at a time," but I sometimes need to, I guess.  I wonder, is acupressure as good as acupuncture? Just curious. Anyway, at least I know I'm not the only one sick of the winter! I'm in Virginia, and we usually have maybe 4-5 days of snow a year. We've gone double past that. Normally this time of year I'd be out planting peas or whatever.  Moondancer, I used to have Silkies! We have only 5 hens at the moment (since I live in the suburbs I'm just grateful to have any) and I really miss silkies. They are so docile and cute. One lady on line had them at her daughter's wedding, dyed pink, with tiaras! She described how a little old lady insisted on knowing what animal it was, and she finally got annoyed and told her, "It's a cross between a poodle and a chicken." She said that somewhere, in some pet store, a little old lady was likely asking for such an animal! (For those of you who don't know what a silkie hen is, google image it and see. They are amazing little birds!!)
Posts.Title: Winter blues raro chris1959

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2014 11:06PM raro wrote: Thanks again, everyone. One thing I've noticed is that I am not eating right. I'm used to eating more fresh fruits and vegetables, and right now winter is just killing that. I don't eat salads in winter, so I try to find other alternatives. But I'm just sick of most veggies. I did find that my local farmer's market will be accepting food stamps this year, and not only that, but they will give an extra $10 for every $10 you spend! So I am thinking that in a month or so I should start feeling a lot better. Not to mention more daylight hours and all that. I'll likely only have food stamps for another month or two, so I want to use them well! I just finished a really sobering book called the Secret History of the War against Breast Cancer. It really pushed for environmental, not genetic, causes of breast cancer. Aside from being depressing (all the conflicts of interest between chemical companies and toxic waste companies and the American Cancer Society, etc.) it made me look at all the negative influences in my life. I know the cancer likely started from something in my childhood that I will never figure out, and I'm okay with that, but I also realized that I haven't been watching the things I have been eating lately, not just in case they cause cancer, but because they influence how I feel. The lousier I eat, the lousier I feel. Pretty simple, huh. Sigh.

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2014 10:40PM raro wrote: Divine Mrs. M., I just read in the paper a few weeks ago about that very issue, of "should doctors tell their patients that they don't think it could be serious, or should they tell them their concerns?" Doctors said that often they don't want the patient to worry unnecessarily, so they spout statistics and try to make light of things. Maybe it's the doctors trying to be in denial, too! But then the doctors (not to mention the patients) feel gobsmacked when it comes back cancer.  My OB/GYN told me, when I told him about the original lump, that "90% of these lumps are noncancerous, so we'll check it out, but it's likely nothing." Yet somehow I knew he didn't really think it was nothing. It did help reassure me so I didn't freak out (I have no family history), but it didn't help at all when I found it was actually cancer.  Then a few years back, my onc commented on the thyroid nodule that kept showing up on my scans. He told me the same thing, that 90% of thyroid nodules were noncancerous. But he was very honest about the fact that it could be cancer and that we needed to biopsy it. And of course, it was thyroid cancer. I sure wish BC were as easy to treat, sigh.  It's funny, because I consider myself "cured" of thyroid cancer, not in remission. I mean, it riddled the thyroid, but had not spread, so they removed the thyroid and the cancer was gone. I would love to say I'm cured of BC (Wouldn't we all!) but even if there were NED for 20 years, I don't know that I would ever get to the point where I could say I was cured.

Posts.Content: Mar 27, 2014 01:06AM raro wrote: Hey there,  My onc said that Xgeva is pretty much what women in danger of osteoporosis get once a year, only we get it once a month. When my dentist balked at doing ANYTHING, my onc called to explain that I could skip a month or two with no problems. He privately explained to me that the Xgeva would still be in my system during that time, but if the dentist knew that, she would flip out and never do anything on my teeth. I had weird "zapping" sensations up and down my spine for the first several days after each shot for maybe 3 months, and since then I've had no side effects whatsoever. I started on Zometa first, then my onc said Xgeva had better results in tests, so we did that. I've been on Xgeva for maybe 2-3 years? No weight gain, no other issues.   For the constipation, I've had it primarily due to narcotic painkillers, so if you're on them, that would be the culprit. My chemo also causes constipation. I found awhile back (and CANNOT find again, grr!!) a paper from the Mayo Clinic about constipation for cancer patients. You can take up to 3 pills 3 times a day, but it has to be a "sennosides"  and "docusate sodium" kind. Others are too harsh or addicting. I get Walmart Equate stool softener, often in a 2-pack. It's got a green label and "compare to Peri-Colace" in tiny letters, in case you want a brand name. I know a lot of people who have great ideas for kicking constipation as an acute issue, but for chronic constipation, this is the only thing that works for me. I take 2 a.m. and 2 p.m. but you can start with 1 a day and move up as you need to.  Hope that helps!

Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2014 11:22AM raro wrote: Oh, can I relate! My house is undergoing renovations, and I don't let ANYONE into my house at the moment. I'm ripping out the carpet (we have 4 cats and a dog) and replacing them with Pergo flooring, which I love. And at the same time we're turning the basement into an apartment for my son and his wife, who are currently living in a tiny bedroom upstairs. It is taking FOREVER. In the meantime, the cats are stressed and the dog (a beagle, who are notorious for their iffy potty training) poos on the living room rug. I make my kids clean it up, but once they've marked their spot, it's a joke trying to get them never to go there again. The best advice I got was from the owner of a dog shelter who said forget about all the chemicals in pet stores, the best deterrent is plain old vinegar. He said that the vinegar smell disappears after about 20 minutes, but the animals can still smell it and will avoid it. It does work, but my house still reeks because of the old accidents and how they got into the carpet padding, etc. But my real shame has been my tub! I finally cleaned it after...well, I'm ashamed to say how long it's been. In fact, I have no idea except that it's been a long time, mostly because I can't bend over and scrub - way too painful. So yesterday I did something I've never tried before, and I wouldn't confess it to anyone but you ladies.. I needed a shower, and my tub needed a bath, so...combine the two, right? I stripped down to nothing and sat in the tub with a container of cleanser and a scrub brush. I scrubbed away all the grayish grime and soap scum buildup. Of course, my butt got all gritty, but hey, the tub got clean, and what better place to wash off then the shower, right? When the tub was sparkling, I stood up, put back my shower chair, and had my shower, while at the same time rinsing off the cleanser. Ta da!!! A clean tub and a clean me. Now if only I can get my kids to clean THEIR tub...

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2014 06:49AM raro wrote: We're renovating our basement, turning it into a 2 bedroom apartment for my son and his wife. When my brother suggested the idea, saying we could "do it ourselves," I just stared at him and then said, "You DO realize that 'do it yourself' implies that I have the physical ability to do more than hammer in a nail, right?!" My brother has great ideas for MY house. But this idea made sense, and with 3 adult children in my home right now, my brother pointed out that I have plenty of free labor.  So I say, go for it! You get to put up with a few days of craziness and weaving your way around piles of stuff, and then, magically, you will have a great bathroom to enjoy. And let's face it we metsters certainly use the bathroom enough! So you might as well enjoy it while you're in there, right?!

Posts.Content: raro wrote: So I was at the library the other day and saw a book about breast cancer. I don't usually get them (I mean, what else can they say that hasn't been said here, right?!) But this one caught my eye. It's called "No Family History: the Environmental Causes of Breast Cancer." It is a relatively easy book to read, but it got me thinking. We have a zillion threads on this forum, but none that have to do directly with breast cancer prevention. Part of it, I think, is the automatic defense mechanisms that come up; heck, we already have breast cancer, what good would it do to talk about prevention, except make us feel guilty for "bringing it on ourselves," right?  But the author, Sabrina McCormick, isn't interested in blame at all. She talks about how scientists are studying the genetics of BC because it's easier than trying to find a correlation between chemicals and BC. For example, is eating a ton of Big Macs bad for you, or is it the non-milk shake we drink with it that causes the problem? With all the environmental issues that surround us, there are likely dozens, if not hundreds, that could cause BC. But she focuses most on those chemicals that have an estrogen-like effect on tissues in the body, disrupting the normal reproductive patterns in a woman's body. I thought I would give just a few highlights, if nobody minds, because it was really fascinating: I'd love to know others' thoughts. Like I said, I'd put it in another section, since it applies to not only stage IV people, but there's no section on prevention and causes of BC. Anyway: - Most scientists of BC discount environment because of the attitude that "everything causes cancer." Yet industrialized cities have much higher rates of BC than do more rural areas. For example, the highest incidents of BC are in Cape Cod, Long Island, and Marin Co. California (that last one has the highest rates in the world). Asian women have the lowest BC rates - until they move to the US, that is, and then they have the same rates as wherever they settled...so how can it be just genetic? - Cape Cod and Long Island were once home to many industrial and factory businesses. Most of the chemicals that were banned there are still found in the homes of women with BC.  -Almost all of the estrogen-like chemicals she discusses are transmitted through breast milk when breastfeeding. - Companies like Avon and AstraZenica have quite the conflict of interest. Avon makes cosmetics that are known to contain carcinogens. Then they do fundraisers in which some of the money goes right back to them. AstraZenica used to be a company that produced chemicals, many of which have been found to cause cancer. Then they found that there was more money to be made in cancer drugs so they gradually switched to that.  - 89% of the 10,500 ingredients in personal care products have not been evaluated for safety. - 55% of those ingredients contain penetration enhancers to enable the product to be more easily absorbed through the bloodstream. - The FDA does not regulate cosmetic ingredients. At all. According to the FDA. "A cosmetic manufacturer may use almost any raw ingredient and market the product without approval from the FDA." - Did you know that AstraZeneca owns the copyright to National Breast Cancer Awareness Month? This means they have the right to sue you if you use that term without their permission. - The pink ribbon had nothing to do with Komen. It was started as a peach ribbon by Charlotte Haley, who sent out hundreds of postcards with a peach ribbon attached to anyone she could think of to raise awareness of BC after losing several relatives. Self magazine and Estee Lauder wanted to use her idea as a marketing gimmick for AZ's National Breast Cancer Awareness Month, but she refused because she felt it was too commercialized. So they got their lawyers and were told they could avoid a lawsuit by changing it to another color ribbon. So of course, they chose pink because it was felt to be the most feminine color. They ran right over Charlotte Haley's peach ribbon and used her idea to sell the public on a gimmick. A whole new reason to hate Pinktober. Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2014 06:25PM raro wrote: Susan, I have never been to Cape Cod, but the author is very specific about what industries were where. She names names (which I didn't pay much attention to since I've never been there). She does point out that the chemicals that were eliminated decades ago are still in the air, dust, and bloodstream of people who have lived there. That was the surprising thing for me in that you'd think those chemicals would have long since dissipated by now.  As to AstraZeneca and the cost of cancer meds, I agree that they're often outrageously expensive, but I was shocked to realize that there is little to no oversight from the government about the costs of the meds. They can charge literally whatever they want. And since they're a business in the business of making money, they charge what they think they can get away with. Anyway, I appreciate the comments! I really wanted to get other people's insights. It's very interesting.

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2014 10:38PM raro wrote: I have 2 adult kids (one married) and a 12-year-old son. They all live with me. I'm grateful to have them, but my youngest often feels like he has 4 parents. He has been dealing with my cancer since he was 4. His dad died when my son was 5 months old, so he is doubly afraid of losing me, as well.  We stayed up late last night talking about the seizures I've had, because I know it scared the wits out of him. We talked about post-traumatic stress, which he has, and that it's okay to be afraid, but we don't want to live our lives in fear. I am glad that he has older siblings to take him to soccer games and all that, but I miss out on so much. But I try to make up for it by cuddling together in the evenings and letting him tell me about his day. We sometimes joke about my mastectomy or my baldness. Like today, we were looking for D batteries, and I peeked down my shirt and said, "Well, I have a double A!" and my kids cracked up. Or when I got my first wig, my kids all tried it on, taking pictures and putting it on the dog and cat.  If we don't laugh, we'll cry, so I try to laugh as much as possible.  I try not to think about how devastated he will be when I pass on. I am hoping to live long enough for him to be an adult, but who knows? I try to be grateful that I have lived as long as I have. I remember when my husband died, I was crying to my sister in law that our son would have no memories of his father, and that broke my heart. Her response was, "We will give him memories." It was such a comforting answer, and she has followed through, making sure to mention stories about his father here and there. I hope I live long enough to provide a world worth of memories for all my kids. .

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2013 01:51PM raro wrote: Chick, I'm "class of 2009" too. What a class to be in! I used to be terrified of the process of dying...maybe gasping for breath or in terrible pain. When my father died of Lewybody dementia (sort of like Parkinson's), he lay in his bed, wasted away, in a sort of half-coma. I had the chance to tell him every last thing I could think of, which helped me. I knew it would be the last time I saw him. The next morning, the nurses told me that they were watching him because they could tell the end was near, and suddenly they heard a shout from across the hall. They raced across, found the other patient sleeping, and came back to my father's room to find he had died.  My father was a private man, and I believe that he wanted to die without nurses gawking at him. As I had watched him, I felt the impression (and it's only my impression, of course) that he was communing with angels, preparing to "cross over." He was able to make the decision when to go in spite of his condition. Even at our weakest, I think we have some control. And I also felt that it would be incredibly presumptuous if I were to try and shorten that time period via euthanasia, etc. I know that's a touchy subject for a lot of people, but in his case I felt he needed those extra days before his passing. I had a friend who was impatiently waiting for her 25th wedding anniversary, but had a stroke several days before. After taking her off the machines, they expected her to die immediately, but she hung on...unconscious, until 12:01 the morning of her anniversary. Then she went downhill immediately and passed. Even in a coma, I know she wanted to make it to her 25th anniversary because it was so important to her. A few months ago, I almost died of pneumonia in the ICU. I would have expected to be struggling to breathe (I was on 100% oxygen, which, if you have never been on it, is nothing like the little stream of air they usually use...it's quite the blast!). But I was so comfortable and peaceful and didn't even feel like moving. My mind wasn't particularly clear - when is it ever?! - but I realized that when my time comes, it will be okay.  I guess what I'm getting at is that if we make the decision to stop treatment, it should feel right..as right as anything feels, that is. If it feels wrong, we keep going. That's all anyone can do. And NOBODY has the right to tell us we're wrong for our decision.  In a weird way, I suppose we are blessed in that we know what is coming and can be sure to make whatever arrangements we want. I personally have decided to write letters to all sorts of people to be delivered after my death, not just family members, but others. I wrote out what I want said at my funeral. I can't do it all at once because it is rather intense and kind of morbid, but there is kind of a release with every letter I write and stash away. Even if by some miracle I don't die, it's certainly a self reflective exercise that has made me a better person. (It's not for everyone, I know. ) We live each day walking through the "Valley of the shadow of death." But we also know more than most people how to live well and what is important in life. I'd still rather not have the cancer, but I try to suck out anything positive from it, however small.

Posts.Content: raro wrote: So yesterday morning I was in a lot of pain in the neck/forehead area. I had just started taking Cymbalta for neuropathy a few days before, and I was going to call my onc to tell him that I just cannot tolerate the headaches they cause.  So I asked my DIL to go get the newspaper while I got out a breakfast dish. And then, suddenly, I was waking up on the floor of my kitchen, with a couple of guys in dark blue calling to me, telling me I'd had a grand mal seizure and they were taking me to the hospital. Apparently, I scared the wits out of my poor DIL, who came in with the paper to find me shaking all over the kitchen floor.  I remember bits and pieces of the ambulance ride. Once at the hospital, they did a CT of the brain, which was fine (yay!). The ER dr said he thought it was because almost 2 years ago I'd had skull surgery and the swelling had caused a seizure way back when, so now I was "predispositioned" for seizures.  I don't think so. I think it was the Cymbalta. Or, rather, the interaction with that drug and several others to produce what they call the "seritonin syndrome." Seizures is one of the side effects of that.  So now I can't drive for SIX MONTHS!!! and I'm all wiped out and sleepy,and my tongue has huge sores in the shape of my molars on either side where I apparently clenched my teeth/tongue during the seizure. And my legs feel like they've been through the wringer, all achy and heavy feeling. I don't know if any of you have had or witnessed a seizure. I'm pretty hard to freak out about medical stuff, but because my kids were so upset, I looked on YouTube to see if I could see what a grand mal seizure looked like. And now I get it...it's freaky and frightening. My poor kids, sigh. Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: May 9, 2014 03:05PM raro wrote: LNM, How long have you been on this current treatment? My onc told me that chemo should take effect pretty quickly if it is going to work, but hormonals can take a few months to really show results. So if you've only been on hormonals for 6 weeks or whatever, I can see his wanting to wait and see.  However, I think it's MORE stressful to "watch and wait" than it is to at least attempt to see if tumor markers are reliable for you. The CTC markers are extremely reliable for me, while the CA-whatever (can NEVER remember that one!) are not at all reliable, so we simply don't use them. Maybe if he knows that you'll be on pins and needles for 3 months (or until your next scans), he might be willing to do tumor markers. If not, I would definitely find a doctor more willing to work with you on that.

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2014 11:04AM raro wrote: Just as a side note... I know there are true allergies and intolerances to milk, but my niece,who has been lactose intolerant all her life, asked me about organic milk. I told her that I prefer it because it doesn't have all the hormones, antibiotics, etc., and it frankly tastes better and lasts much longer.  She called me up the next day, very excited. She had bought some organic milk and had been trying little bits of it all day long...and had absolutely no problem. Then she drank a glass of "regular" milk, and all her issues returned.  I have heard the same thing about gluten intolerance in wheat. Why is it that when my mom was a kid, no one had ever heard of gluten intolerance (or even, according to her, any kind of wheat/bread intolerance or allergies)? But some people who are supposedly intolerant to gluten find that consuming organic wheat is perfectly safe.  I'm not trying to discount those who have true allergies or intolerance to foods. But sometimes it may just not be the food itself, but the pesticides, hormones, dyes, or other additives that are the true problem. And a lifetime of consuming those additives, plus a genetic disposition, plus stress, pollution, you name it...and there's the "perfect storm" of breast cancer.

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2012 04:36AM raro wrote: Well, my update... I received today (Merry Christmas to me, haha) an 8-page "summary review" that listed, in minute detail, everything my principal felt I had done wrong in the past year and a half. He concluded that we needed to meet by January 11th to discuss where we were at, and "if no improvements are seen by mid-April, I will recommend termination." My union rep is really nice, but I think from her comments that her boss wants her to resolve things without the cost of a lawyer, and I don't see that happening. So after escaping home and stewing awhile, I remembered that a lady at my church is...on the school board! My sister-in-law reminded me, but at first I was hesitant, as I don't know her very well and felt like I was asking favors from her. She told me no, I'm asking my school board representative for clarification and help. So I called her, and she was very nice and says we can meet after Christmas next week. She agrees that it sounds like he is trying to get rid of me. I'm bringing all my papers and documentations and I'm hoping she will be able to help. Janis, I would give ANYTHING to be able to go on disability. My school does not offer STD or LTD. I could get on SSDI but could not pay COBRA, so I would be out of insurance for 2 years, which I can't do. SSDI payments would not even pay the mortgage on my house, unfortunately. Then again, my sister-in-law said that if it goes as far as a lawsuit, I should sue for them to pay for my disability...I found out that this principal last year fired one of the teachers, and he sued for wrongful termination...and won. He got his retirement package plus a settlement. I can't even look into a different school because I'm on this stupid improvement plan that he won't let me get off of, and you can't transfer while on it. And I can't try for a different county, because who would hire someone with all those letters of reprimand in their file? (Of course, the fact that they are all from the last year and a half might tell them something...) Anyway, I'm just feeling way sorry for myself right now. I wanted so much to stay and fight, but I have realized it's affecting my health. I was having heart palpitations and I think high blood pressure, feeling dizzy and faint. I can't work like this. And to top it all off, I'm REALLY feeling sorry for myself because all the teachers and staff were giving gifts to one another today...and I didn't get so much as a card or a cookie. I truly am invisible there. Talk about weird...in the 7 years I have worked there, I've given little gifts to those I've worked with every year. And not one of these professional people has even said thank you. Not one. I gave up this year. When the only time you ever get noticed is when you do something wrong, well, it grates on your soul. All I wanted was to teach these troubled kids. This past week I helped them make really useful presents for their parents/guardians...soup in a jar and cookies in a jar (where you layer the dry ingredients in a jar with instructions on how to make the soup/cookies). The kids were thrilled to make something for the adults in their lives that wasn't an ornament or bookmark. And I gave them sock monkeys for Christmas. They LOVED them. And I got in trouble because one of them hit another kid in the hall with his sock monkey. The principal called it an "incident." Seriously? Death by sock monkey?!

Posts.Content: raro wrote: I am Mandy, Raro's daughter. It's taken me a bit of time to post this, since I wasn't sure what to say or how to say it, but I finally was able to have a few minutes to sit down and write, and I hope I can write it well. I don't even know if this is the right place to post it, and if it isn't, I'm incredibly sorry, I don't know my way around these forums. My beautiful, amazing, intelligent, incredibly wonderful mother died early on Tuesday morning. She managed to hold on for the last ten years to make sure that her children were taken care of and spent much of her time in pain and discomfort from the cancer that betrayed her body, which I know most of you understand already. By the end, she was struggling so hard just to breathe, and she had lost control of both her body and her sense of self, unable to speak or do much more than wait. She fought hard until the very end, which might sound cliche, but having taken care of her all this time, she wasn't willing to go so easily; but when she finally did, it was very peaceful, and very quiet, and she had her children with her, as well as several family members and friends that came after. She cared a great deal for you all here. I know that much; she talked often of you, and spoke extremely highly of the people on her forum, because you and she understood each other in ways that most people could not. Even I couldn't fully comprehend some of the things she experienced, but the fact that she had this place to come when she needed that understanding was a source of relief to the both of us. She was often very touched by your messages and comments, and would relate to me on a daily basis just how much she loved talking to you all. If there are any of you who wish to pay their respects, an open house will be held on Monday, February 23rd, at 161 Eustace Road, Stafford, Virginia, from 6-8pm. It will be followed by the funeral on Tuesday, February 24th, at 10am at the same address. I can also be reached via Private Message. Thank you so, so much for your time of love and care towards my mother. You have no idea how much it has meant to both of us over the past several years. Posts.Content: Dec 24, 2012 10:42PM raro wrote: Wow.So much to consider, thanks everyone! A few things: I'm in Virginia. Apparently my school district is self-insured. I don't really understand that part, but I mentioned to the school board lady that could it be possible they were trying to get rid of me because of the cost? She said the principal would not because it wouldn't affect how much money he gets, but the superintendant...She paused and thought a minute and then said, no, she really did not think he was the type. She said it sounded like the principal is a control freak who is intimidated both by the students I work with and the cancer. I think she is right. After my husband died, my sister-in-law asked about life insurance for me. I had no money at all, so she invested in some life insurance for me as a gift. I asked her about taking it out and apparently it's the wrong kind. (Term vs. whole? I can't remember if that's the issue or not). I was pretty bummed. I've only been working for 7 years, and I'm 46 years old, so it's not like I have enough invested to retire. It used to be that the county paid into our retirement for us as a benefit, but that went out the window last year. Now we pay for it. And I'm sure it isn't much. So many other teachers are at the point where they can consider retiring. But SSDI wouldn't pay my mortgage. It would be around a thousand dollars, and my mortgage is 1400. I do pay into SS, though. I don't know if I could even get unemployment if I was fired for being supposedly incompetent? One thing I did this year might help somewhat. The county changed insurers or something, and they made available some extra programs that normally I couldn't qualify for, but if I pay the premiums all this year, then Oct 1 of 2013 I will qualify. It's STD, I think up to 17 weeks. And the lady told me that it's unrelated to my regular health insurance. I asked what about if I go on a new chemo in June...she said I could take the whole summer and get disability payments. I said, but I don't work in the summer, and she said who cares? I'm legally employed, so I would get the payments! The other is a cancer rider, where they send a check for cancer-related stuff, even if it's already covered by my regular insurance. That's assuming that I'm still employed next year, though, sigh. From what I understand, if I'm actually fired, can I get unemployment? And if I do, does that lower the COBRA pay? I know so little and like you said, I need to get my ducks in a row.  I'm frustrated because the union doesn't want to get me a lawyer (it's supposed to be a FREE benefit!) because it's expensive for them. So the union rep is trying to make nice and solve the problem without one. But I was talking to my brother tonight, and he said, "This is a situation that you cannot win with this guy. He is determined to get rid of you, and is even MORE upset when you do things right. You could be Jesus Christ and it would never be good enough for him." Rather dramatic, but he is right. Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2014 10:02PM raro wrote: I'm so sorry your friend has malignancy in her spinal fluid. I've been getting weekly spinal taps to check for it, and this past Monday, the 5th one, they sent back a path report saying there were cells that were "concerning for malignancy." I spoke with my onc (because I was devastated, along with the rest of the crap I've dealt with this month) and he basically said that it's like a biopsy, so if I have cancer cells in the cerebro-spinal fluid, it means there is cancer in the  brain. So I asked him if I could gamma-knife the brain, and unfortunately, if your friend is like me, there aren't actual blobs of cancer to zap. He likened it to sand scattered across my brain. So the only option would be Xeloda (which I failed years ago, but he felt it was never really given a chance) or whole brain rads, which I swore I'd never do. But now that it looms in front of me as a possibility, who knows. The symptoms of cancer in the CSF are frankly frightening, but the more you know the more you can help. For me, there have been seizures (now under control, but originally terrifying), blurred vision, cognitive function issues (I forget EVERYTHING, much more than the usual chemo-brain) and I guess what you'd call hand-eye coordination (I constantly have to back-space on the computer because my hands won't type what my brain tells them to). So if your friend doesn't recognize you, it may be scary, but it could be temporary and/or depending how close you are, if you were wearing different clothing she might not have recognized you. Sounds weird, but if I saw someone at church every week in a dress, then I see them in sweats at the supermarket, I'd have a hard time remembering who they were and where I knew them from.  I asked my dr. about prognosis and he was very kind but also very honest...usually the life expectancy is about six months. He hurried to assure me that not everyone had poor response to treatment, so i shouldn't worry too much about the statistics, but that's easier said than done. There is really no way to tell if this issue with your friend is just a bump in the road or the beginning of the end.  Even so, she is blessed to have someone like you who cares for her. Even if she doesn't recognize you, you are doing a wonderful thing to want to take care of someone who is struggling through such trials.

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2014 01:54AM raro wrote: I had a nurse say something similar about 3 years ago. It left me in tears, and I'm not usually a weepy person. I came home and told my sister. She did what I was too stressed to do: called up and asked to speak with the office manager, and then calmly explained that this particular nurse was normally decent, but what she had said was so over the top rude that we just HAD to let her know, because we were sure she would want to do something about it.  The next time I went, you would not believe the kindness, the apologies, and the special treatment! The office manager thanked me for bringing it to her attention. Turned out that nurse had been having a terrible day and just lost it. So I felt better about it not being personal, and the nurses were all made much more aware of sensitive issues. And the funny thing is, I can't remember what the original comment was to save my life! Reader,this is not a time to "play nice." You aren't a bad person if you calmly call and ask to speak with someone in charge. You may be surprised at how better you feel simply for calling out someone on their rudeness, especially if you can do it in a calm way. RoseValley, I had to pick my jaw up off the floor after reading your post! If I lived anywhere near you I'd take your daughter for respite in a heartbeat. NOBODY, and I mean nobody, understands what it's like to care for a child with a disability, especially when you're disabled yourself from cancer. You and your hubby deserve a vacation together! And I hate to break it to those people, but a child with a disability IS the state's responsibility as well as her parents'.  Just yesterday my brother found out about my possibly getting the accelerated death benefit on my insurance, and he joked that, "Wow, maybe I should get cancer and apply for all these programs and get rich!" He said it in a totally joking way, but I have the feeling from my stunned silence that his comment went over like a lead balloon. I finally just said dryly, "I think I'm going to ignore that comment." I give him the benefit of the doubt because he is normally such a great support. But wow.

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2013 09:24PM raro wrote: My onc insisted on a liver biopsy when I got liver mets in addition to bone mets. He said bone mets are notoriously hard to get definitive HER2 status and that things could change. The way he explained it, if the anti-hormonals killed off 95% of the cancer cells, the remaining 5% could be of a different cellular structure. When they say you're "75% PR positive,: it means 75% of the cells looked at had the receptors. Well, the other 25% would be negative, and those may be the ones that burst forth, immune to the anti-hormonals.  My onc said that the breast cancer that you have 3 years down the road could be very different from the cancer you started with. Weird. My cancer did change, but I went from ER+ to ER and PR+ which makes no difference in treatment.  And a liver biopsy is no big deal. Took a few hours at the hospital and came out with a a bandaid on my tummy. Didn't hurt at all.

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2014 03:16PM raro wrote: I'm like Fitz, I got it in the groin area, too. It was about 3 years ago, and I was about to start rads to the sacrum, so I was terrified that they would put it off. I was already in terrible back/butt pain. I showed the nurse, and she took one look (right in the crease where your leg meets your body) and said, "Oh, honey, you've got shingles!" Fortunately I could still do the rads. I ended up in the hospital with a totally different issue, but they put a sign on my door saying I had shingles. And EVERY single nurse, aide, or doctor who entered the room wanted to look at it, even the pulmonologist, etc.!! And they all put gloves on, etc. as if it were contagious (who knows, maybe it is?!). I joked that I was growing mushrooms in that area because the blisters were HUGE. Acyclovir was what I think they gave me. The pain did recede after a few days to an annoyance, then faded. But from the start, It felt as though (sorry if this is TMI) some pubic hairs were caught in my undies or something. I could hardly walk, and it's not like you can tell people at work where the rash is!  So yes, the pain does start to fade after a few days on treatment. For me, the pain was completely gone by maybe 8 days? And I have fortunately had NO lasting issues with it. And I am very grateful I didn't have the rash in some places that the nurse told me about (vaginal, eyeballs, etc.). Ick!! It's probably cold comfort at the moment, though. They did give me some sort of cream to put on it that helped numb it. There are all sorts of numbing creams; surely they have SOMETHING that works on shingles! Unfortunately, you have to be persistent and your own advocate and all that. Grr.

I know very little about diabetes except that my mom has it. I always felt that I would eat right and exercise and somehow avoid getting it, but I never thought the medicine that is keeping me alive would actually cause me to have diabetes. I was hoping maybe someone out there might have some words of wisdom for me. All I know is that my hemoglobin A1C is nine, so my regular doc put me on Janumet. She talked about how insulin would get my sugars down faster, but I just cannot face poking myself right now. So I'm doing the pills. I've already got a hideous rash all over my face, a thumb that became septic over the weekend, requiring hospital stay, a mouth with the worst case of thrush my doctor has ever seen (along with telling me "You know, you have some wicked sores in your mouth, too!" I am 46 years old and have been fighting cancer for 7 years. But it's the stupid little things that make me break down and fall apart. Terrible cramps in my legs. Horrid, sour taste in my mouth. Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2013 10:15PM raro wrote: Evans, we women tend to feel guilt for all the wrong reasons. The guilt of "bad mom" is the depression talking.
